description: September 24, 2016 is the last day for this exam. CCNA Overview The Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA) is the most well known Cisco certification path. It takes the general networking theory from the CCENT certification and applies it in real world scenarios. It moves beyond configuring individual devices into more complex territory often requiring the configuration of numerous devices to create a robust and optimized network. While studying for this certification, you will revisit the routing and switching topics from the CCENT in more depth as you learn about and implement the advanced features of each technology.
name: CCNA Routing and Switching
subtitle: Cisco Certified Network Associate

episodes.description: CCNA Overview The Cisco Certified Network Associate (CCNA) is the most well known Cisco certification path. It takes the general networking theory from the CCENT certification and applies it in real world scenarios. It moves beyond configuring individual devices into more complex territory often requiring the configuration of numerous devices to create a robust and optimized network. While studying for this certification, you will revisit the routing and switching topics from the CCENT in more depth as you learn about and implement the advanced features of each technology.
episodes.title: Overview of CCNA Routing and Switching
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,311
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,311 --> 00:00:10,622
The Cisco Certified Network Associate,
or CCNA,

3
00:00:10,622 --> 00:00:15,520
is one of the most well-known
certifications in IT networking.

4
00:00:15,520 --> 00:00:20,060
It's designed to demonstrate that you
have a intermediate level of knowledge

5
00:00:20,060 --> 00:00:23,680
with Cisco equipment, particularly
their routers, and their switches.

6
00:00:23,680 --> 00:00:27,550
Now there are multiple versions
of the CCNA, and for this

7
00:00:27,550 --> 00:00:32,400
particular ITProTV show, we're talking
about the CCNA routing and switching.

8
00:00:32,400 --> 00:00:34,030
Focus is on routers and switches.

9
00:00:34,030 --> 00:00:37,880
There's also the CCNA security,
which focuses on the ASA firewalls,

10
00:00:37,880 --> 00:00:41,670
and several other variations that focus on
other things, like wireless, and voice,

11
00:00:41,670 --> 00:00:43,770
service provider equipment and so on.

12
00:00:43,770 --> 00:00:45,180
But the CCNA routing and

13
00:00:45,180 --> 00:00:49,880
switching, that's the one most
people think of when they say, CCNA.

14
00:00:49,880 --> 00:00:53,620
The certification's designed to show
that you understand how to take Cisco

15
00:00:53,620 --> 00:00:58,330
routers and Cisco switches from
a factory default configuration, and

16
00:00:58,330 --> 00:01:00,950
get them configured in
small to medium networks.

17
00:01:00,950 --> 00:01:05,600
We're talking about networks that range
in size from 10 to 100 routers or

18
00:01:05,600 --> 00:01:07,440
10 to 100 switches.

19
00:01:07,440 --> 00:01:12,040
In mixed environments, a headquarters and
branch offices, that type of situation.

20
00:01:12,040 --> 00:01:16,460
And there are various technologies we need
to configure that go beyond just a basic

21
00:01:16,460 --> 00:01:20,210
router configuration like what you might
have in a small office or home office.

22
00:01:20,210 --> 00:01:25,000
There's also some advanced functionality
the routers and switches can do that move

23
00:01:25,000 --> 00:01:30,040
beyond basic functionality, and start to
get our switches acting more like routers,

24
00:01:30,040 --> 00:01:33,700
or our routers performing functions
that traditional routers don't even do.

25
00:01:33,700 --> 00:01:36,380
So, really interesting
stuff that's out there.

26
00:01:36,380 --> 00:01:39,620
CCNA is one of the more rewarding
certifications I find in that you

27
00:01:39,620 --> 00:01:41,560
just learn a lot of cool
stuff that you can do.

28
00:01:41,560 --> 00:01:44,670
So it's a good time, and
it's a fun certification to get.

29
00:01:44,670 --> 00:01:47,430
It's one of the favorite ones
that I've gotten over the years.

30
00:01:47,430 --> 00:01:51,320
Now, if you want to pursue this CCNA,
there's a few things we need to remember.

31
00:01:51,320 --> 00:01:55,910
First off, it is expected that
you already have the CCENT.

32
00:01:55,910 --> 00:01:59,200
The Cisco Certified Entry
Network Technician.

33
00:01:59,200 --> 00:02:02,080
So if you're just getting
started with Cisco,

34
00:02:02,080 --> 00:02:05,510
you should probably jump over to
the CCENT show and start there.

35
00:02:05,510 --> 00:02:08,780
That's designed for people that have not
worked with Cisco equipment before and

36
00:02:08,780 --> 00:02:10,540
are just getting started.

37
00:02:10,540 --> 00:02:13,650
But if you've already got some experience
with Cisco equipment, if you've set up

38
00:02:13,650 --> 00:02:17,005
a few routers and switches,
you've already got that basic knowledge.

39
00:02:17,005 --> 00:02:20,270
And you'll find that the CCENT
might be a little boring or

40
00:02:20,270 --> 00:02:22,830
beneath your knowledge level,
because you've already done it.

41
00:02:22,830 --> 00:02:26,480
And for you,
you can start right here in the CCNA.

42
00:02:26,480 --> 00:02:31,250
Just understand that Cisco will assume
you have the knowledge of the CCENT.

43
00:02:31,250 --> 00:02:34,370
So I encourage you just to read over the
outline for that exam, and just make sure

44
00:02:34,370 --> 00:02:38,250
you don't see anything in there that
jumps out at you as new or unexpected.

45
00:02:38,250 --> 00:02:41,585
If you see anything, maybe you just watch
those particular episodes of the CCENT.

46
00:02:42,730 --> 00:02:46,520
So, there are two different ways
to get the CCNA routing and

47
00:02:46,520 --> 00:02:48,020
switching certification.

48
00:02:48,020 --> 00:02:51,890
And it all comes down to whether
you have that CCENT or not.

49
00:02:51,890 --> 00:02:52,420
Alright.

50
00:02:52,420 --> 00:02:53,780
Let me show you what I mean.

51
00:02:53,780 --> 00:02:56,700
Here's the Cisco webpage for
the CCNA routing and switching.

52
00:02:56,700 --> 00:02:58,580
And you'll see it's
a mid-tier certification.

53
00:02:58,580 --> 00:03:02,240
It's above the CCENT, but
not at the professional level of a CCENP.

54
00:03:02,240 --> 00:03:07,770
And for the exams,
there's two different exam scenarios.

55
00:03:07,770 --> 00:03:11,600
If you already have
the CCENT certification,

56
00:03:11,600 --> 00:03:13,690
that's this exam right here, the 100-101.

57
00:03:13,690 --> 00:03:18,820
So if you've completed that certification,
then you just need to do

58
00:03:18,820 --> 00:03:23,880
the 200-101 exam, or the ICND2 exam,
and that will get you your CCNA.

59
00:03:24,980 --> 00:03:30,000
If you don't have your CCENT,
then you'll do the 200-120 exam.

60
00:03:30,000 --> 00:03:31,920
This guy right here.

61
00:03:31,920 --> 00:03:36,500
And it's made up of questions
drawn from both exams,

62
00:03:36,500 --> 00:03:40,310
drawn from the 100-101 and the 200-101.

63
00:03:40,310 --> 00:03:44,140
So it's called a composite exam,
it just combines them together.

64
00:03:45,180 --> 00:03:50,630
Now, the composite exam is the same
cost as adding these two together.

65
00:03:50,630 --> 00:03:53,690
So you don't save money by doing that,
you just save time.

66
00:03:53,690 --> 00:03:55,790
The exam, well, it takes time.

67
00:03:55,790 --> 00:03:58,020
It takes you going down to
the testing center and taking it.

68
00:03:58,020 --> 00:03:59,960
So, two exams versus one exam.

69
00:03:59,960 --> 00:04:01,830
It's just all about how
much time you have.

70
00:04:01,830 --> 00:04:05,610
Personally, I encourage people
to complete the CCENT first.

71
00:04:05,610 --> 00:04:09,220
But, while I do encourage people
to do that, I didn't do it myself.

72
00:04:09,220 --> 00:04:12,640
The CCENT wasn't when I
got certified originally.

73
00:04:12,640 --> 00:04:15,690
But even today, I've never gone
back to do it because, well,

74
00:04:15,690 --> 00:04:18,620
once you have the advanced
certifications you don't really need it.

75
00:04:18,620 --> 00:04:21,740
But it is great if you're getting
started out because it gives you a nice

76
00:04:21,740 --> 00:04:23,620
easy entry point into the certification.

77
00:04:24,850 --> 00:04:28,110
Now the exam itself covers
a wide range of topics.

78
00:04:28,110 --> 00:04:31,400
It covers everything in the CCENT outline,
and

79
00:04:31,400 --> 00:04:34,030
then it goes beyond that with
the advanced functionality.

80
00:04:34,030 --> 00:04:38,010
And you're really just getting to larger
networks in the CCNA side, and so

81
00:04:38,010 --> 00:04:41,500
it's really working with
the same stuff from CCENT,

82
00:04:41,500 --> 00:04:43,820
just making it a little more complex.

83
00:04:43,820 --> 00:04:44,860
Let's look at the actual exam.

84
00:04:46,020 --> 00:04:52,150
The exam is between 50 and 60 questions,
and it is only 75 minutes long.

85
00:04:52,150 --> 00:04:55,530
Now that sounds like you get
about a minute per question,

86
00:04:55,530 --> 00:05:00,030
which is enough for
a multiple choice question I suppose.

87
00:05:00,030 --> 00:05:02,600
But, you don't really have
a lot of time to dally.

88
00:05:02,600 --> 00:05:04,300
You need to know the right answer.

89
00:05:04,300 --> 00:05:06,690
You read the question, and you answer it.

90
00:05:06,690 --> 00:05:09,310
You don't sit there and think,
well let me see, is it like this?

91
00:05:09,310 --> 00:05:10,240
Is it like that?

92
00:05:10,240 --> 00:05:13,865
They don't give you enough time to try and
extrapolate an answer on your own.

93
00:05:13,865 --> 00:05:16,030
You gotta know it and move on.

94
00:05:16,030 --> 00:05:19,160
The other thing that makes it more
challenging is they're not just multiple

95
00:05:19,160 --> 00:05:20,000
choice questions.

96
00:05:20,000 --> 00:05:24,290
You'll see drag and drop questions,
and you'll see stimulation questions.

97
00:05:24,290 --> 00:05:26,830
Ones where they give you
a simulated set of routers or

98
00:05:26,830 --> 00:05:28,430
a stimulated set of switches.

99
00:05:28,430 --> 00:05:30,210
And you have to troubleshoot or

100
00:05:30,210 --> 00:05:32,780
configure some functionality
that they've described to you.

101
00:05:32,780 --> 00:05:34,740
So you've actually got to get in there and
do some work.

102
00:05:34,740 --> 00:05:36,700
Those questions take some time.

103
00:05:36,700 --> 00:05:39,270
And if you spend too long doing those,

104
00:05:39,270 --> 00:05:42,120
you might not be able to get to
all the questions on the exam.

105
00:05:42,120 --> 00:05:46,310
So it is very important that you study,
that you practice, and

106
00:05:46,310 --> 00:05:48,450
that you're ready when you go
into that testing booth so

107
00:05:48,450 --> 00:05:50,169
you know the content
they're going to be asking.

108
00:05:51,670 --> 00:05:55,400
The exam is proctored through Pearson VUE,
which is an international company.

109
00:05:55,400 --> 00:05:58,650
They have testing centers
located all around the world and

110
00:05:58,650 --> 00:06:00,650
more than likely have one near you.

111
00:06:00,650 --> 00:06:04,080
You can find out by going to
www.pearsonvue.com/cisco.

112
00:06:04,080 --> 00:06:08,860
That'll take you to
their page where you can

113
00:06:10,030 --> 00:06:13,970
check for
a testing center that's nearest to you.

114
00:06:13,970 --> 00:06:17,230
You can register for the exam,
pay for it, go and take the exam.

115
00:06:17,230 --> 00:06:20,480
And then when you pass,
you'll receive you'r CCNA certification.

116
00:06:20,480 --> 00:06:23,410
Now the exam topics themselves,

117
00:06:23,410 --> 00:06:27,350
I'll just scroll down here a little bit,
are divided up into five areas.

118
00:06:27,350 --> 00:06:28,610
We start with switching.

119
00:06:28,610 --> 00:06:33,130
There's a lot of switching technologies
that didn't get addressed in

120
00:06:33,130 --> 00:06:34,380
the CCENT certification.

121
00:06:34,380 --> 00:06:38,770
So in CCENT, for example, we talked about
spanning tree protocol a little bit.

122
00:06:38,770 --> 00:06:42,350
And so we'll see more advanced
spanning tree protocol here.

123
00:06:42,350 --> 00:06:44,480
As well as VLAN trunking protocol and

124
00:06:44,480 --> 00:06:48,310
other technologies related to
more advanced functionality.

125
00:06:48,310 --> 00:06:51,480
You'll also get your first
introduction to layer three switching,

126
00:06:51,480 --> 00:06:53,510
which are switches that act like routers.

127
00:06:53,510 --> 00:06:55,390
And that's pretty neat stuff
cuz we're seeing more and

128
00:06:55,390 --> 00:06:57,660
more of those out in the real world.

129
00:06:57,660 --> 00:06:59,070
Then we go into routing.

130
00:06:59,070 --> 00:07:03,510
And notice the routing and switching
combined makes up almost 50% of the exam.

131
00:07:03,510 --> 00:07:06,880
So about half of the exam is made
up of practical configurations.

132
00:07:06,880 --> 00:07:09,660
And on the routing side we start moving
into advanced routing protocols.

133
00:07:09,660 --> 00:07:14,770
Things like EIGRP and OSPF, and
getting a chance to see how they work,

134
00:07:14,770 --> 00:07:16,890
and how they optimize your network and
make decisions.

135
00:07:18,100 --> 00:07:19,530
Then, we get into IP services.

136
00:07:19,530 --> 00:07:23,440
Now, IP services makes up a smaller
portion of the exam because, well,

137
00:07:23,440 --> 00:07:25,580
a lot of it was covered in CCENT.

138
00:07:25,580 --> 00:07:30,190
But the other IP services have kind
of been shifted off to the CCNA

139
00:07:30,190 --> 00:07:33,620
security certification or
wireless service provider.

140
00:07:33,620 --> 00:07:36,590
So they've kind of been moved over
to those other certifications.

141
00:07:36,590 --> 00:07:39,350
So here it's more of a informational,
you know, making sure we

142
00:07:39,350 --> 00:07:42,280
understand what are some of the different
IP services that are available.

143
00:07:43,320 --> 00:07:44,380
Then we got troubleshooting,

144
00:07:44,380 --> 00:07:47,750
and make troubleshooting makes
up one-third of the exam.

145
00:07:47,750 --> 00:07:51,890
A big chunk of the exam
on just how to figure out

146
00:07:51,890 --> 00:07:55,890
why something isn't working the way
that it should, and how to correct it.

147
00:07:55,890 --> 00:07:59,320
And then we wrap it talking about wide
area network, or WAN technologies.

148
00:07:59,320 --> 00:08:04,560
We get a chance to see things like frame
relay, get a little introduction on MPLS.

149
00:08:04,560 --> 00:08:07,180
And a couple of the other
technologies you might see out there

150
00:08:07,180 --> 00:08:08,780
as you get connected to the Internet, or

151
00:08:08,780 --> 00:08:11,830
at least get long distance connections
between different locations.

152
00:08:11,830 --> 00:08:15,180
So, good information, definitely
things that we want to know, and

153
00:08:15,180 --> 00:08:19,655
it's all gearing us up to be able
to configure medium size network.

154
00:08:19,655 --> 00:08:24,500
Networks with a headquarters, the branch
offices, with 10 to a 100 devices,

155
00:08:24,500 --> 00:08:28,520
routers and switches that are out there,
and a pretty good size network.

156
00:08:28,520 --> 00:08:31,120
So, it's a great certification to get.

157
00:08:31,120 --> 00:08:34,050
This is normally the certification
that people target

158
00:08:34,050 --> 00:08:38,200
when they're ready to go out there and
get their first network administrator job.

159
00:08:38,200 --> 00:08:41,310
Prior to this a lot of people
will have more generic type jobs,

160
00:08:41,310 --> 00:08:44,790
jobs where you're part system admin,
part network admin.

161
00:08:44,790 --> 00:08:46,840
But once we start going all network,

162
00:08:46,840 --> 00:08:49,220
CCNA is usually the first
step that gets us there.

163
00:08:49,220 --> 00:08:53,800
So it is a great certification, and
one that I really enjoyed myself.

164
00:08:53,800 --> 00:08:56,900
Well if that sounds like something you
wanna do, then you're in the right place.

165
00:08:56,900 --> 00:09:01,080
Stay tuned, we've got our CCNA
episodes coming up in just a moment.

166
00:09:01,080 --> 00:09:03,770
If, on the other hand,
you aren't in the right place,

167
00:09:03,770 --> 00:09:07,200
if you wanna go check out the CCENT first,
definitely do so.

168
00:09:07,200 --> 00:09:09,580
It's all part of your
ITProTV subscription, so

169
00:09:09,580 --> 00:09:12,380
just jump right over there and
watch it, right?

170
00:09:12,380 --> 00:09:16,250
So for those of you that need to do that,
go ahead, no hard feelings there.

171
00:09:16,250 --> 00:09:19,160
But for those of you that are sticking
with me, well, stay tuned.

172
00:09:19,160 --> 00:09:21,436
We've got episodes coming up next.

173
00:09:21,436 --> 00:09:27,679
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don describe loop prevention on Cisco switches. They describe how Spanning Tree Protocol (IEEE 802.1d), Per VLAN Spanning Tree Protocol, Rapid Spanning Tree Protocol (IEEE 802.1w) operate and how it makes its decisions for loop prevention. They also demonstrate configuration of each protocol.

00:02:27,560 --> 00:02:31,740

00:02:43,100 --> 00:02:47,420

00:02:47,420 --> 00:02:52,330

47
00:02:52,330 --> 00:02:57,160

48
00:02:57,160 --> 00:02:59,510

Usernames, doesn't support subfolders,

So normally you hear of people

as well as the IOS to a TFTP server.

00:03:23,786 --> 00:03:24,350

00:03:24,350 --> 00:03:27,080
>> Once again, it actually does that very

00:03:35,231 --> 00:03:36,960
On the exam

75

the basics here for when we do this.

00:04:16,690 --> 00:04:18,070

00:05:13,840 --> 00:05:16,660

so it's a neat little program.

96

97
00:05:18,360 --> 00:05:22,348

00:05:22,348 --> 00:05:26,421

00:05:26,421 --> 00:05:29,170
3 Com has one that you can download for

00:05:29,170 --> 00:05:30,930

102
00:05:36,660 --> 00:05:39,470

00:05:39,470 --> 00:05:42,260

00:05:42,260 --> 00:05:44,820

00:05:44,820 --> 00:05:47,150

106
00:05:47,150 --> 00:05:52,010
And inside of that I just have my IP
on my laptop that this is attached to.

107
00:05:52,010 --> 00:05:52,560
And here it's going.

108
00:05:52,560 --> 00:05:53,660
I don't have to set usernames.

109
00:05:53,660 --> 00:05:56,462
I don't have to set passwords,
I don't have to set folders, it's just,

00:05:56,462 --> 00:05:58,162

00:05:58,162 --> 00:05:59,320

00:06:07,000 --> 00:06:11,040

00:06:11,040 --> 00:06:16,290

00:06:16,290 --> 00:06:19,730

00:06:19,730 --> 00:06:25,020

00:06:25,020 --> 00:06:27,770

00:06:27,770 --> 00:06:31,170

00:06:37,553 --> 00:06:42,950

124

125
00:06:48,060 --> 00:06:52,670

126
00:06:52,670 --> 00:06:54,650
I've got secure copy protocol.

00:07:15,964 --> 00:07:19,190

136
00:07:27,450 --> 00:07:29,540
>> Right.

00:07:29,540 --> 00:07:31,330

138
00:07:31,330 --> 00:07:35,090
In the background, I can see

00:07:35,090 --> 00:07:39,960

140
00:07:39,960 --> 00:07:40,920
>> Yeah.

00:07:44,498 --> 00:07:45,967

144
00:07:51,028 --> 00:07:52,274
>> [LAUGH] Oh.
>> So in Windows,

145
00:07:52,274 --> 00:07:55,500
at the end of every line in a text

146
00:07:55,500 --> 00:07:56,278
>> Mm-hm.

147
00:07:56,278 --> 00:07:57,159
>> And a line feed.

148
00:07:57,159 --> 00:08:01,388
In munics land, they only do the line
feed, they don't do the carriage return.

149
00:08:01,388 --> 00:08:04,510
So it doesn't start a new line.

150
00:08:04,510 --> 00:08:07,560
So let me open that in Wordpad instead.

151
00:08:07,560 --> 00:08:09,050
Wordpad will be a little happier with it.

152
00:08:10,250 --> 00:08:11,020
>> There you go.

153
00:08:11,020 --> 00:08:12,140
>> There we go.

154
00:08:12,140 --> 00:08:13,580

155
00:08:13,580 --> 00:08:17,350
All the commands that would need to be
entered to get my router back to the exact

00:08:17,350 --> 00:08:19,903
configuration as it was,
let me turn off word wrap.

157
00:08:22,774 --> 00:08:24,060
There we go.

158
00:08:24,060 --> 00:08:27,850
Everything that would need to be run to
get my router back into the configuration

00:08:27,850 --> 00:08:29,010

from before except this time I'm gonna do

the startup config.

169
00:09:03,815 --> 00:09:05,170
There we go.

00:09:10,034 --> 00:09:11,764
Aw snap.

00:09:11,764 --> 00:09:13,130

so as we start to look at these,

01:17:27,840 --> 01:17:29,660
that previous customer.

1550
01:17:29,660 --> 01:17:31,210
Probably some company that
went out of business though,

1551
01:17:31,210 --> 01:17:32,750
that's usually where a lot
of the equipment comes from.

1552
01:17:33,940 --> 01:17:38,610
But I know I've bought stuff that was
decommissioned military equipment before,

1553
01:17:38,610 --> 01:17:42,590
which they're not supposed to
sell on eBay, and it had configs.

1554
01:17:42,590 --> 01:17:46,710
It does happen.

1555
01:17:46,710 --> 01:17:50,240
So basically password recovery,
not that big of a deal.

1556
01:17:50,240 --> 01:17:51,530
There are other ways to do it.

1557
01:17:51,530 --> 01:17:55,350
For example I could have used TFTP and
just copy a configuration back,

1558
01:17:55,350 --> 01:17:57,370
or other things of that nature.

1559
01:17:57,370 --> 01:17:58,870
Several different ways to go about it.

1560
01:18:00,110 --> 01:18:04,110
If you bought the new device, and
you don't care about the config,

1561
01:18:04,110 --> 01:18:06,250
you don't wanna recover it like we did.

1562
01:18:06,250 --> 01:18:10,020
Instead you can do an erase
start up dash config, and

1563
01:18:10,020 --> 01:18:11,790
that just wipes out
that config altogether.

1564
01:18:11,790 --> 01:18:13,420
You can start from scratch.

1565
01:18:13,420 --> 01:18:16,888
If you just bought the router,
that's probably what you want to do.

1566
01:18:16,888 --> 01:18:18,540
Right.

1567
01:18:18,540 --> 01:18:20,885
One comment I will make,
when you do an erase start up config,

1568
01:18:20,885 --> 01:18:23,265
that does wipe the configuration,
that's good.

1569
01:18:23,265 --> 01:18:25,945
It doesn't format the flash or
anything, so

1570
01:18:25,945 --> 01:18:28,805
there may still be other
files sitting there in flash.

1571
01:18:28,805 --> 01:18:32,325
A lot of times people back up the
configuration to other files, then flash.

1572
01:18:32,325 --> 01:18:36,790
So you might need to get in there and
do a little, spring cleaning.

1573
01:18:36,790 --> 01:18:37,420
And kinda get it set.

1574
01:18:37,420 --> 01:18:40,180
>> Yeah, just be careful
about deleting the actual IOS

1575
01:18:40,180 --> 01:18:41,360
on the flash when you do it.

1576
01:18:41,360 --> 01:18:42,060
>> Yeah.

1577
01:18:42,060 --> 01:18:44,390
And really,
that's the only critical file in the IOS.

1578
01:18:44,390 --> 01:18:49,400
Some of them will have like web user
interface, the SDM or whatever in there.

1579
01:18:49,400 --> 01:18:52,730
But a lot of them,
it's just the IOS file and that's it.

1580
01:18:52,730 --> 01:18:56,090
As soon as this one gets to where
I can issue commands again,

1581
01:18:56,090 --> 01:18:58,225
I'll show you guys what I mean.

1582
01:18:58,225 --> 01:19:03,720
>> [LAUGH]
>> We'll give it a second.

1583
01:19:03,720 --> 01:19:06,200
So, whenever I do an upgrade of a router

1584
01:19:06,200 --> 01:19:09,260
I know that the new IOS might
not support some old commands.

1585
01:19:09,260 --> 01:19:13,100
So if I'm in testing or whatever, I may
back up the IOS file, or the config file.

1586
01:19:13,100 --> 01:19:14,840
And I might back it up
right to this router.

1587
01:19:14,840 --> 01:19:16,890
So let me show you an example.

1588
01:19:16,890 --> 01:19:17,390
Whoops.

1589
01:19:19,280 --> 01:19:21,430
All right.
So if I know I'm gonna upgrade,

1590
01:19:21,430 --> 01:19:25,753
I might do a copy running-config to

1591
01:19:25,753 --> 01:19:31,520
flash:/prior-to-upgrade.txt or

1592
01:19:31,520 --> 01:19:36,700
dot conveyor or whatever,
so I'll call it that.

1593
01:19:36,700 --> 01:19:39,510
So what it's gonna do, oh,
why's it gonna erase my flash?

1594
01:19:39,510 --> 01:19:40,010
Dadgummit.

1595
01:19:41,860 --> 01:19:42,720
There we go.

1596
01:19:42,720 --> 01:19:43,608
I just said no.

1597
01:19:43,608 --> 01:19:45,050
[LAUGH] I don't want it to erase my flash.

1598
01:19:45,050 --> 01:19:46,980
I just want it to copy this dadgum file.

1599
01:19:46,980 --> 01:19:50,770
It apparently though I was copying
an IOS instead of the config.

1600
01:19:50,770 --> 01:19:52,262
You defiantly want to be careful there.

1601
01:19:52,262 --> 01:19:57,260
So now when I do a /dir see how I've
got my ios files right there, and

1602
01:19:57,260 --> 01:20:00,525
now I've got another text file right here.

1603
01:20:00,525 --> 01:20:02,360
That's got my configuration.

1604
01:20:02,360 --> 01:20:04,641
So I might do an upgrade on my system.

1605
01:20:04,641 --> 01:20:06,260
So I upgrade all my stuff.

1606
01:20:06,260 --> 01:20:09,082
And after the upgrade I noticed
some commands were missing, but

1607
01:20:09,082 --> 01:20:12,582
I didn't document them or I wasn't plugged
into the console when it booted up so

1608
01:20:12,582 --> 01:20:14,140
I didn't get to see it.

1609
01:20:14,140 --> 01:20:16,530
Well now I've got a backup of
my config right here in flash.

1610
01:20:16,530 --> 01:20:18,820
Flash doesn't get erased when we reboot,
so

1611
01:20:18,820 --> 01:20:23,090
it'll be there and I can always reload it.

1612
01:20:23,090 --> 01:20:29,444
I can say copy flash:/prior-to-upgrade.txt

1613
01:20:29,444 --> 01:20:34,300
to running-config, and
now it'll copy it into running.

1614
01:20:34,300 --> 01:20:37,560
Now it'll do a merge with
whatever's in running right now.

1615
01:20:37,560 --> 01:20:42,125
If I wanted to truly revert to that, the
best thing to do would be to do an erase

1616
01:20:42,125 --> 01:20:47,920
startup-config, which is gonna wipe
the configuration of the router, right?

1617
01:20:47,920 --> 01:20:49,310
So here we go, it's just gonna wipe it.

1618
01:20:50,540 --> 01:20:51,930
So the configuration is wiped.

1619
01:20:51,930 --> 01:20:54,860
The IOS is still there, but
the configuration is wiped.

1620
01:20:54,860 --> 01:21:01,450
So now there is no startup config and if I
do a dir, there's my prior to upgrade and

1621
01:21:01,450 --> 01:21:06,848
I can say copy to startup-config.

1622
01:21:06,848 --> 01:21:12,970
Now that startup config was empty,
it's being replaced by this one.

1623
01:21:12,970 --> 01:21:15,650
And now it's all back in there.

1624
01:21:15,650 --> 01:21:17,733
And if I do a reload, we'll reboot and

1625
01:21:17,733 --> 01:21:21,338
we will be back to the way that it
was when we made that backup file.

1626
01:21:21,338 --> 01:21:24,000
So that's an example of the other
types of files you might find in

1627
01:21:24,000 --> 01:21:24,887
flash just sitting around.

1628
01:21:24,887 --> 01:21:29,250
So, all right.

1629
01:21:29,250 --> 01:21:32,020
Well Ronnie,
as far as manipulating the files and

1630
01:21:32,020 --> 01:21:34,815
stuff, I think that's pretty much it.

1631
01:21:34,815 --> 01:21:36,130
I kind of tapped out.

1632
01:21:36,130 --> 01:21:39,710
I will say that for every router that I
work on, one of the first things I do is

1633
01:21:39,710 --> 01:21:44,050
back up its IOS files so I've got a whole
collection of IOS files from the years.

1634
01:21:44,050 --> 01:21:47,040
But it is a good idea to back them up,
and then you've got that copy.

1635
01:21:47,040 --> 01:21:50,470
You can always download it from Cisco,
but if you lose Internet access.

1636
01:21:50,470 --> 01:21:52,240
>> Yeah.
>> You may not have that access to Cisco.

1637
01:21:52,240 --> 01:21:53,980
So I like to keep back up copies myself.

1638
01:21:55,120 --> 01:21:57,150
Just make sure you do your backups,
it's real easy.

1639
01:21:57,150 --> 01:22:00,940
You can whip up a TFTP server or
FTP server really simple, really quick.

1640
01:22:00,940 --> 01:22:02,910
Do your backups, and
then you got that safety net.

1641
01:22:02,910 --> 01:22:04,870
No matter what you do,
no matter how bad things get,

1642
01:22:04,870 --> 01:22:07,100
you got that backup you can always load.

1643
01:22:07,100 --> 01:22:08,340
>> Yep.

1644
01:22:08,340 --> 01:22:10,430
So we went through a lot of stuff today.

1645
01:22:10,430 --> 01:22:11,680
>> Yeah, it's good stuff.

1646
01:22:11,680 --> 01:22:13,900
I thought we could get in done
in one show, but apparently not.

1647
01:22:13,900 --> 01:22:16,200
So, all right, well ladies and

1648
01:22:16,200 --> 01:22:19,480
gentleman as always if you have questions
make sure you go to our website.

1649
01:22:19,480 --> 01:22:24,470
Live during the show itpro.tv/live, the
chatroom is right beneath the live video.

1650
01:22:24,470 --> 01:22:25,460
You can post your questions.

1651
01:22:25,460 --> 01:22:27,080
We monitor and answer during the show.

1652
01:22:27,080 --> 01:22:29,320
If you have questions after the show,

1653
01:22:29,320 --> 01:22:31,640
on the top of every single
page is a link that says Q&A.

1654
01:22:31,640 --> 01:22:35,580
You can go into the Question and Answer
area, post your questions, we monitor and,

1655
01:22:35,580 --> 01:22:36,720
oddly enough, answer.

1656
01:22:36,720 --> 01:22:38,032
>> [LAUGH]
>> So it's almost like that's

1657
01:22:38,032 --> 01:22:38,630
why we named it.

1658
01:22:38,630 --> 01:22:39,875
>> Maybe even odd answers.

1659
01:22:39,875 --> 01:22:41,430
>> [LAUGH]
>> All right, so

1660
01:22:41,430 --> 01:22:44,120
definitely keep that in mind as
a resource available for you guys.

1661
01:22:44,120 --> 01:22:45,420
Definitely take advantage of that.

1662
01:22:45,420 --> 01:22:46,020
>> Right.

1663
01:22:46,020 --> 01:22:49,420
>> Otherwise signing out for
IT Pro TV, I'm Don Pezet.

1664
01:22:49,420 --> 01:22:50,190
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

1665
01:22:50,190 --> 01:22:51,570
>> And we'll see you next time.

1666
01:22:51,570 --> 01:23:01,570

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don re-examine dynamic routing protocols and build on to the topics covered in the CCENT show. They cover administrative distance and loop prevention mechanisms as well as other routing topics.
episodes.title: Routing Protocols
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:31,059 --> 00:00:33,906
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening,

and welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:36,081 --> 00:00:38,498
I'm your host Don Pezet
today with Mr Ronnie Wong.

5
00:00:38,498 --> 00:00:39,880
How's it going Ronnie?

6
00:00:39,880 --> 00:00:41,590

7
00:00:41,590 --> 00:00:45,530
I am doing much better than any mayor from
Toronto trying to get in to the US to see

00:00:45,530 --> 00:00:46,320

00:00:46,320 --> 00:00:48,615
>> I don't know, it sounds like he's

10
00:00:48,615 --> 00:00:51,810
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, you know,

11
00:00:51,810 --> 00:00:53,230
I think it is funny, though,

12
00:00:53,230 --> 00:00:57,700
on an international level that politicians
are pretty much the same everywhere.

13
00:00:57,700 --> 00:00:59,710
We picked the wrong career apparently,
Ronnie.

14
00:00:59,710 --> 00:01:02,580
No sex, drugs, and rock and roll here.

15
00:01:02,580 --> 00:01:04,600
All right, so

16
00:01:04,600 --> 00:01:09,640
today we had an exciting Cisco episode
before us, or a CCNA more particularly.

17
00:01:10,830 --> 00:01:12,640
We've done many episodes now.

18
00:01:12,640 --> 00:01:15,020
I've kinda lost track of how many
episodes we've done on CCNA.

19
00:01:15,020 --> 00:01:18,370
That have all focused on
managing the routers.

20
00:01:18,370 --> 00:01:19,240
Stuff on a single router.

21
00:01:19,240 --> 00:01:22,180
Now we're going to get into the good
stuff, the routing protocols.

22
00:01:22,180 --> 00:01:25,770
>> Yeah, kind of took a look, just
briefly, about switching technologies.

23
00:01:25,770 --> 00:01:30,830
But really on the CCNA we're
focusing in on the router portion

24
00:01:30,830 --> 00:01:32,630
of switches and routers.

25
00:01:32,630 --> 00:01:34,510
So we're going to go much
more in depth in this.

26
00:01:34,510 --> 00:01:37,850
So much so
that it should help you to prepare for

27
00:01:37,850 --> 00:01:41,290
the CCNA exam in routing and switching.

28
00:01:41,290 --> 00:01:43,726
And so we want to make sure,
in this particular episode,

29
00:01:43,726 --> 00:01:46,460
that we go over the basics
of routing protocols for us.

30
00:01:46,460 --> 00:01:49,350
And make sure we have a solid
understanding of the fundamentals and

31
00:01:49,350 --> 00:01:51,240
theories behind how
routing actually works.

32
00:01:51,240 --> 00:01:54,700
>> Now for those of you who are following
along in the objective list,

33
00:01:54,700 --> 00:01:58,650
this is objective 2.4.

34
00:01:58,650 --> 00:02:02,170
Differentiate methods of routing and
routing protocols.

35
00:02:02,170 --> 00:02:04,910
So we're gonna take a look at some of
the routing protocols that are out there,

36
00:02:04,910 --> 00:02:08,040
the categories they fall in, and
how we can differentiate between them.

37
00:02:08,040 --> 00:02:10,850
Now we did that in the CCENT show.

38
00:02:10,850 --> 00:02:14,100
So for those of you who already watched
that show, that may sound familiar.

39
00:02:14,100 --> 00:02:16,940
Well we're gonna go a little
bit more in depth this time.

40
00:02:16,940 --> 00:02:21,060
But in this particular episode we're
still going to stay fairly general.

41
00:02:21,060 --> 00:02:24,760
And then we're going to jump into
the episodes that focus entirely on

42
00:02:24,760 --> 00:02:26,430
OSPF and ERGIP.

43
00:02:26,430 --> 00:02:29,130
And those really exciting ones that we,
well,

44
00:02:29,130 --> 00:02:32,380
with OSPF we barely touched on in CCENT.

45
00:02:32,380 --> 00:02:37,290
And EIGRP I don't even think we mentioned,
so we'll really dive into those.

46
00:02:37,290 --> 00:02:41,680
>> So when we take a look especially about
the idea of routing, since we did do

47
00:02:41,680 --> 00:02:46,392
almost a complete series on
switching technologies really.

48
00:02:46,392 --> 00:02:49,530
We wanna focus in on the idea of routers.

49
00:02:49,530 --> 00:02:53,620
Now one of the things that I remember that
I had a problem with when I first began

50
00:02:53,620 --> 00:02:57,420
was understanding what is the difference
between a switch and a router.

51
00:02:58,460 --> 00:03:01,240
In other words, if I have a switch,
why do I need a router?

52
00:03:01,240 --> 00:03:04,290
If I have a router, why in the world
would I need a switch here?

53
00:03:04,290 --> 00:03:06,620
So we talked about the idea
of the switches but

54
00:03:06,620 --> 00:03:08,660
now we're going in that routing portion.

55
00:03:08,660 --> 00:03:10,990
Don is there an easy way to,
to, to describe that?

56
00:03:10,990 --> 00:03:12,800
The difference in that?

57
00:03:12,800 --> 00:03:15,150
>> For the viewers that
have been paying attention,

58
00:03:15,150 --> 00:03:17,030
it's layers two versus layer three.

59
00:03:17,030 --> 00:03:19,980
So switches are layer two devices, right?

60
00:03:19,980 --> 00:03:25,160
They're just moving frames between
ports on a local area network.

61
00:03:25,160 --> 00:03:28,480
They dont provide you any support if
event you have more than one network.

62
00:03:28,480 --> 00:03:31,310
If you have more than one subnet,
switches are not aware of that,

63
00:03:31,310 --> 00:03:33,120
theyre dead in the water.

64
00:03:33,120 --> 00:03:34,895
A router is aware of that.

65
00:03:34,895 --> 00:03:39,080
It's able to move that traffic
from one subnet to another, and

66
00:03:39,080 --> 00:03:43,110
it does that by using its
layer three routing table.

67
00:03:43,110 --> 00:03:45,230
Every router maintains a table.

68
00:03:45,230 --> 00:03:48,440
It list what routes it's aware of and
how to get to them.

69
00:03:48,440 --> 00:03:50,900
And that's really what
we need to know here.

70
00:03:50,900 --> 00:03:54,000
And its objectively saying how can
we differentiate between the routing

71
00:03:54,000 --> 00:03:54,570
protocols?

72
00:03:54,570 --> 00:03:56,730
Well, what the heck is a routing protocol?

73
00:03:56,730 --> 00:03:59,520
We showed you guys in CCENT, that

74
00:03:59,520 --> 00:04:04,440
one way to get your routers to be aware
of other network is to do static routes.

75
00:04:04,440 --> 00:04:10,002
And a static route is where I manually
enter in what route is available where,

76
00:04:10,002 --> 00:04:11,100
all right?

77
00:04:11,100 --> 00:04:15,010
And that's fine if you've got a handful
of devices and it's not a big deal,

78
00:04:15,010 --> 00:04:16,250
you can knock it right out.

79
00:04:16,250 --> 00:04:17,580
But if you've got hundreds or

80
00:04:17,580 --> 00:04:22,050
thousands of devices out there,
we have dynamic routing protocols,

81
00:04:22,050 --> 00:04:25,230
where the routers will talk to each
other and they'll exchange information.

82
00:04:25,230 --> 00:04:28,850
They'll learn the routes from each other,
so we don't have to get manually involved.

83
00:04:28,850 --> 00:04:31,020
And there's a lot of benefits to that.

84
00:04:31,020 --> 00:04:34,040
But there's several different
dynamic routing protocols.

85
00:04:34,040 --> 00:04:38,540
So we need to be able to know which
one to use in which scenario.

86
00:04:38,540 --> 00:04:41,770
>> So when we dive into a little
bit more of a review for right now,

87
00:04:41,770 --> 00:04:45,180
but it does help as we begin
to get deeper in to it.

88
00:04:45,180 --> 00:04:48,690
We want to talk about the two,
I guess there's really three basic

89
00:04:48,690 --> 00:04:52,200
differentiations between different
types of routing protocols.

90
00:04:52,200 --> 00:04:54,470
There is what we call
Distance Vector Routing Protocols.

91
00:04:54,470 --> 00:04:56,990
There is what we call Link State.

92
00:04:56,990 --> 00:05:00,220
And then the third one,
depending on who you talk to, you

93
00:05:00,220 --> 00:05:04,875
either call it a Hybrid Routing Protocol
or an Advanced Distance Vector Protocol.

94
00:05:04,875 --> 00:05:08,420
So when we begin with that
idea of distance vector and

95
00:05:08,420 --> 00:05:12,190
link state,
those are the ones we tend to see.

96
00:05:12,190 --> 00:05:13,930
And distance vector's actually for

97
00:05:13,930 --> 00:05:17,420
the CCNA exam kind of almost
disappearing all right.

98
00:05:17,420 --> 00:05:18,770
>> In a way yep.

99
00:05:18,770 --> 00:05:21,930
It's kinda tricky,
we'll cover all that, but yeah.

100
00:05:21,930 --> 00:05:23,200
let's start with the distance vector.

101
00:05:23,200 --> 00:05:25,990
Let me, i'm gonna bring up
a simple diagram I sketched real

102
00:05:25,990 --> 00:05:27,180
quick before the show.

103
00:05:27,180 --> 00:05:30,790
And let me, let me share my desktop.

104
00:05:30,790 --> 00:05:32,640
And all right,

105
00:05:32,640 --> 00:05:36,390
so here's just a quick diagram that
I knocked out before the show.

106
00:05:36,390 --> 00:05:42,080
I just wanted to show a couple of
routers and a couple of networks.

107
00:05:42,080 --> 00:05:44,760
And so I got the 192.168.0
network attached to router two.

108
00:05:44,760 --> 00:05:47,410
And I've got the 192.168.1
network attached to router three.

109
00:05:47,410 --> 00:05:51,690
The networks are there, router two,
router three, they're aware of it.

110
00:05:51,690 --> 00:05:54,620
Now when you power on a router,

111
00:05:54,620 --> 00:06:00,390
it will automatically know about any

if that link were to fail and

1472

1475

If it does, our routing table sees it and
says oh and it's safe.

1476
01:16:17,480 --> 01:16:20,900
Let's go ahead and switch back over there,
and now we can move across that line and

1477
01:16:20,900 --> 01:16:21,870
get back to our destination.

1478
01:16:23,260 --> 01:16:27,500
However, sometimes and you'll see this
with like T1 lines, or ISDN lines.

1479
01:16:27,500 --> 01:16:28,970
You use to always have an ISDN.

1480
01:16:28,970 --> 01:16:32,080
If you have any of your
configuration's slightly wrong,

1481
01:16:32,080 --> 01:16:35,460
then what may happen is
the interface may come up.

1482
01:16:35,460 --> 01:16:39,420
The router thinks it's up,
starts sending traffic,

1483
01:16:39,420 --> 01:16:43,500
and it realizes that it's not actually up,
and takes are back down again.

1484
01:16:43,500 --> 01:16:46,040
And then it comes back up and
it repeats the process.

1485
01:16:46,040 --> 01:16:50,200
It does what's called flapping, the route
comes up and goes down and then up and

1486
01:16:50,200 --> 01:16:51,830
then down, over and over.

1487
01:16:51,830 --> 01:16:53,090
>> The result of this, of course,

1488
01:16:53,090 --> 01:16:55,352
means that what you end up with
on these different routers,

1489
01:16:55,352 --> 01:16:59,560
is you'll end up getting routing tables
that are relatively inconsistent.

1490
01:16:59,560 --> 01:17:02,850
A moment one route actually says hey,
everything's good.

1491
01:17:02,850 --> 01:17:06,070
Next moment, another packet goes through
saying no I don't have a route for this.

1492
01:17:06,070 --> 01:17:08,600
And then a few moments later,
it'll actually do it again.

1493
01:17:08,600 --> 01:17:11,590
So you end up dropping packets,
pretty quickly here.

1494
01:17:11,590 --> 01:17:17,210
So for us here The whole idea of
understanding this route flapping is that.

1495
01:17:17,210 --> 01:17:20,260
Is making sure that we understand that
you'll get those routing tables that will

1496
01:17:20,260 --> 01:17:22,580
not actually match up to
anything that we need to so

1497
01:17:22,580 --> 01:17:25,980
they're not gonna provide a consistent
route all the way through for us.

1498
01:17:25,980 --> 01:17:29,500
>> So the solution here is that most of
our routers will implement what is called

1499
01:17:29,500 --> 01:17:30,710

1500
01:17:30,710 --> 01:17:33,680

great, it's down,

1501
01:17:33,680 --> 01:17:35,880
let's find another path, right.

01:17:35,880 --> 01:17:41,530
But if the route comes back up, let's not
put it in the routing table right away.

1503
01:17:41,530 --> 01:17:42,070
>> Right.

1504
01:17:42,070 --> 01:17:47,020
>> Let's wait a moment to ensure
that it's actually up and if it is,

1505
01:17:47,020 --> 01:17:49,530
then we bring it into the routing table,
all right.

01:17:49,530 --> 01:17:51,740

wait a minute, Don,

aren't we talking about loops?

How does this help us with loops?

And let me give you an example.

01:17:56,910 --> 01:18:00,510
I talked about poison reverse
a few moments ago, right?

1511
01:18:00,510 --> 01:18:03,040
And with poison reverse,
what we do is we say all right,

1512
01:18:03,040 --> 01:18:05,900
if router three is connected
to this network and

1513
01:18:05,900 --> 01:18:11,440
it's advertising it out, and
it's coming back to itself like this.

1514
01:18:11,440 --> 01:18:17,380
Well, when router three's link fails,
it sends out a poison message.

1515
01:18:17,380 --> 01:18:20,950
And that poison message goes up to
router one saying delete the route.

1516
01:18:20,950 --> 01:18:23,310
And router one goes down to router two and
says delete the route.

1517
01:18:23,310 --> 01:18:26,820
And router two goes to router three saying
delete the route, but it's already gone.

1518
01:18:26,820 --> 01:18:32,970
So this process takes some time so
if router three loses it's link and

1519
01:18:32,970 --> 01:18:37,160
it sees this route coming from router two,
it might say that's a great route.

1520
01:18:37,160 --> 01:18:38,180
Let me take it.

1521
01:18:38,180 --> 01:18:41,190
I want it, but if it waits, if it says,

1522
01:18:41,190 --> 01:18:43,740
you know what,
I'm going to hold it down for 30 seconds.

1523
01:18:43,740 --> 01:18:46,620
Let me hold this link down for
30 seconds and see what happens.

1524
01:18:46,620 --> 01:18:48,280
Well in 30 seconds.

1525
01:18:48,280 --> 01:18:51,280
Router one should learn that
the route is gone and delete it.

1526
01:18:51,280 --> 01:18:54,190
And router two would learn that
the route is gone and delete it.

1527
01:18:54,190 --> 01:18:57,180
And then it will stop
advertising it to router three.

1528
01:18:57,180 --> 01:19:00,560
So now even if router three wanted it,
it couldn't switch to it, and

1529
01:19:00,560 --> 01:19:02,330
the loop doesn't get created.

1530
01:19:02,330 --> 01:19:02,840
Right?

1531
01:19:02,840 --> 01:19:07,090
So hold-down timers are really effective
because they can suppress route flapping,

1532
01:19:07,090 --> 01:19:10,310
they can make sure a route is actually
up before they switch it, and

1533
01:19:10,310 --> 01:19:13,750
it can prevent loops by giving
us a little bit of a delay

1534
01:19:13,750 --> 01:19:16,355
before we cut over to a route
that may in fact be bad.

1535
01:19:18,695 --> 01:19:21,315
Now the negative of a hold down timer

1536
01:19:21,315 --> 01:19:23,415
is that it makes it take
longer to fail abroad.

1537
01:19:23,415 --> 01:19:26,775
If a link goes down, you might have
a perfectly good route in place, but

1538
01:19:26,775 --> 01:19:28,715
it doesn't cut over to it immediately.

01:19:28,715 --> 01:19:30,995
And so of the various technologies

a configuration, all right?

>> I drew a little network map here and

00:05:01,530 --> 00:05:06,584
You've got this kind of area in
here where I've got R1, R2, and

R3, and they are all plugged

>> Mm-hm.
>> And

Now, another comment I

These routers are the same

I left them there because

00:06:15,070 --> 00:06:17,640
>> Yeap.

118
00:06:17,640 --> 00:06:19,810

00:06:19,810 --> 00:06:21,160
they're independent of each other.

00:06:43,350 --> 00:06:45,860

00:06:53,100 --> 00:06:57,780

00:06:59,490 --> 00:07:03,210

134
00:07:05,140 --> 00:07:06,100
>> Yeah.

135
00:07:06,100 --> 00:07:09,100
So let's take a look at
a basic OSPF configuration, so

136
00:07:09,100 --> 00:07:11,590
we're gonna start with Router 1.

137
00:07:11,590 --> 00:07:15,970
Router 1's just got one interface, FA0/0,
and we want to assign an IP to it.

138
00:07:15,970 --> 00:07:19,550
So the basic configuration
looks something like this.

139
00:07:19,550 --> 00:07:23,050
The first thing that we need to do
is issue this command right here,

140
00:07:23,050 --> 00:07:29,060
this is the most important command,

141
00:07:29,060 --> 00:07:34,610

it's not normally turned on by default.

142
00:07:34,610 --> 00:07:38,480

addresses you want, but it's not going to

143
00:07:38,480 --> 00:07:43,720
actually route them until you run
the IPV 6 unicast-routing command.

144
00:07:43,720 --> 00:07:45,020
So that's a pretty important command for
us.

145
00:07:45,020 --> 00:07:45,650
>> Right.

146
00:07:45,650 --> 00:07:48,232
A lot of times, it's so
important we normally say,

147
00:07:48,232 --> 00:07:52,417
it should be the first command you ever
do when you're actually configuring IPV6.

148
00:07:52,417 --> 00:07:56,568
So, I've seen this happen cuz I've done
it myself where I've configured it on one

149
00:07:56,568 --> 00:08:00,208

the other one that I was working with.

150
00:08:00,208 --> 00:08:01,400
Like why isn't it working?

151
00:08:01,400 --> 00:08:03,917
Well I forgot that very
important command here.

152
00:08:03,917 --> 00:08:06,000
IPv6 unicast-routing.

153
00:08:06,000 --> 00:08:08,625
>> Yeah cuz it'll let you run all
the other commands it doesn't stop you.

154
00:08:08,625 --> 00:08:14,111
[LAUGH] All right after that,
we then need to get into our interface and

155
00:08:14,111 --> 00:08:16,500

156
00:08:16,500 --> 00:08:20,270
So that's what we're showing here is
IPv6 enabled that turns on IPv6 for

157
00:08:20,270 --> 00:08:21,360
the interface.

158
00:08:21,360 --> 00:08:25,090
And then IPv6 address and
then what address we're gonna use.

159
00:08:25,090 --> 00:08:28,840
So, this is nothing we didn't
see in the CCENT show here.

160
00:08:28,840 --> 00:08:34,059
Here we're just assigning a simple
short address 2003::1/64.

161
00:08:34,059 --> 00:08:36,346
Then, here's where things
get a little different.

162
00:08:36,346 --> 00:08:42,002
Under IPv4, when you configured OSPF,
you would go into the OSPF process number,

163
00:08:42,002 --> 00:08:46,063
and then you would punch in
the whole network in a subnet, and

164
00:08:46,063 --> 00:08:50,370
subnet mask,
followed by an area number and all that.

165
00:08:50,370 --> 00:08:53,000
In IPv6,
you just turn it on on the interface.

166
00:08:53,000 --> 00:08:56,800
And you could do that under IPv4 also,
it was a secondary way of doing it.

167
00:08:56,800 --> 00:09:01,060
But in IPv6 world,
it's the primary way of doing it.

168
00:09:01,060 --> 00:09:07,810
On the interface, when you say
IPv6 OPSF1 area 0, just like that.

169
00:09:07,810 --> 00:09:11,590
What you're doing is you're saying take
whatever IPv6 networks are on this

170
00:09:11,590 --> 00:09:19,620
interface and add them to OSPF process
number one and add them into area 0.

171
00:09:19,620 --> 00:09:22,590
This eliminates the need of
those old network commands.

172
00:09:22,590 --> 00:09:25,830
You don't have to worry about
wildcard masks and stuff like that.

173
00:09:25,830 --> 00:09:29,520
It's entered right here
on the interface itself.

174
00:09:29,520 --> 00:09:33,050
If I were to stop right there,
OSPF is done.

175
00:09:33,050 --> 00:09:36,210
I never actually have to
get into the OSPF process.

176
00:09:36,210 --> 00:09:38,269
You can just do it all from
the interfaces and you're done.

177

we think and make sure that you guys

635
00:34:06,920 --> 00:34:09,970
have a good understanding of the topics
before you go into that testing booth and

636
00:34:09,970 --> 00:34:11,010
take that exam.

637
00:34:11,010 --> 00:34:14,030
So definitely take advantage of
that resource it's there for you.

638
00:34:15,070 --> 00:34:17,478
All right, well signing off for
ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet.

639
00:34:17,478 --> 00:34:18,569
>> I'm Ronnie Wong.

640
00:34:18,569 --> 00:34:19,126

641
00:34:19,126 --> 00:34:20,019
>> And we'll see you next time.

642

All right, good morning,

18

19
00:01:02,362 --> 00:01:05,060
All right, well ladies and gentlemen,

20
00:01:05,060 --> 00:01:09,710
today we are diving into
the wonderful world of EIGRP.

21
00:01:09,710 --> 00:01:12,050
Which is some acronym soup for us,

22
00:01:12,050 --> 00:01:16,180
the enhanced interior
gateway routing protocol.

23
00:01:16,180 --> 00:01:20,670
And if you've been a fan of the series so
far then you probably just watched

24
00:01:20,670 --> 00:01:25,230
the OSPF episode,
the open shortest path first protocol.

25
00:01:25,230 --> 00:01:28,100
And that was our first
chance to see a truly

26
00:01:28,100 --> 00:01:30,830
full featured dynamic routing protocol.

27
00:01:30,830 --> 00:01:31,650
It's pretty cool.

28
00:01:31,650 --> 00:01:32,680
>> Yeah
>> Right?

29
00:01:32,680 --> 00:01:33,930
Very common protocol,

30
00:01:33,930 --> 00:01:37,130
probably the most common used in most
corporations that are out there.

31
00:01:37,130 --> 00:01:38,450
But today we are gonna look at EIGRP.

32
00:01:38,450 --> 00:01:42,070
And you are gonna notice a lot
of parallels between EIGRP and

33
00:01:42,070 --> 00:01:45,890
OSPF, but keep in mind some
of the major differences and

34
00:01:45,890 --> 00:01:47,700
maybe we should start out right there,
Ronnie.

35
00:01:47,700 --> 00:01:50,490
Our basic kind of description.

36
00:01:50,490 --> 00:01:55,390
>> Yeah, but when it comes down to it, and
Don we've talked about this before, Don,

37
00:01:55,390 --> 00:01:59,160
you said a EIGRP is
actually a better protocol,

38
00:01:59,160 --> 00:02:03,330
and more sophisticated
protocol than the OSPF, right?

39
00:02:03,330 --> 00:02:06,750
And, so when we mention this here,
the reason why is that there's

40
00:02:06,750 --> 00:02:11,030
a ton of additional benefits that
they came out with, with EIGRP.

41
00:02:11,030 --> 00:02:15,190
And the strange thing about EIGRP, is
that it really began as kind of a dog of

42
00:02:15,190 --> 00:02:20,030
a protocol in terms of the older
IGRP that was introduced by Cisco,

43
00:02:20,030 --> 00:02:22,560
but they really didn't actually
do a good job with it at all.

44
00:02:22,560 --> 00:02:24,620
And so they decided to improve on it.

45
00:02:24,620 --> 00:02:27,520
And so there's a lot of
features that we wanted to talk

46
00:02:27,520 --> 00:02:30,560
about here when we start talking about
the idea of the advancements that we have.

47
00:02:30,560 --> 00:02:32,550
>> Yeah, so
the original protocol was IGRP,

48
00:02:32,550 --> 00:02:35,210
the interior gateway routing protocol.

49
00:02:36,320 --> 00:02:38,490
Like Ronnie said,
it was an older protocol.

50
00:02:38,490 --> 00:02:41,190
Definitely had some pretty
big limitations on it.

51
00:02:41,190 --> 00:02:43,350
And so Cisco improved upon it and

52
00:02:43,350 --> 00:02:47,080
made EIGRP the enhanced Interior
gateway writing protocol.

53
00:02:47,080 --> 00:02:48,630
So it's enhanced, it's better.

54
00:02:48,630 --> 00:02:49,380
>> Yeah.
>> That's it.

55
00:02:49,380 --> 00:02:50,244
>> Yeah.
>> Episode's over, right?

56
00:02:50,244 --> 00:02:52,540
[LAUGH]
>> Sure, we're ready to go here.

57
00:02:52,540 --> 00:02:57,200
Some of the advancements actually did help
us because as the internet continued to

58
00:02:57,200 --> 00:03:00,180
develop, we started actually
needing more and more IP addresses.

59
00:03:00,180 --> 00:03:04,290
So it really helped us by actually
being able to handle things like Syder.

60
00:03:04,290 --> 00:03:06,460
And the idea of VLSF.

61
00:03:06,460 --> 00:03:08,130
So being able to do route summarization,

62
00:03:08,130 --> 00:03:11,830
as well as being able to do subnetting,
whereas the original one couldn't do it.

63
00:03:11,830 --> 00:03:14,310
They simply had to follow
the class full addressing.

64
00:03:14,310 --> 00:03:17,460
That's one of the benefits
that really did help out with.

65
00:03:17,460 --> 00:03:19,450
>> Yeah, unlike OSPF.

66
00:03:19,450 --> 00:03:23,160
OSPF has pretty much been classless
since the very beginning.

67
00:03:23,160 --> 00:03:26,430
And OSPF was kind of its
own individual invention.

68
00:03:26,430 --> 00:03:28,218
EIGRP, on the other hand, does not, right?

69
00:03:28,218 --> 00:03:29,202
>> Mm-hm.

70
00:03:29,202 --> 00:03:32,160
>> We don't really talk too
much about it on the exams too

71
00:03:32,160 --> 00:03:32,830
much anymore
>> Yeah.

72
00:03:32,830 --> 00:03:36,620
>> But we used to have to learn
RIP version one, and IGRP.

73
00:03:36,620 --> 00:03:39,660
Both of those are very old
routing protocols, and

74
00:03:39,660 --> 00:03:41,690
they were developed in the classful days.

75
00:03:41,690 --> 00:03:43,750
>> Mm-hm.
>> So they did classful routing.

76
00:03:43,750 --> 00:03:45,690
That meant you had to adhere
to the Class A, B, and

77
00:03:45,690 --> 00:03:48,210
C nomenclature and all that stuff.

78
00:03:48,210 --> 00:03:50,880
And you had to make sure
you follow the rules.

79
00:03:50,880 --> 00:03:52,250
Well, we don't do that anymore.

80
00:03:52,250 --> 00:03:54,580
Like Ronnie said,
as the IP addresses started to run out,

81
00:03:54,580 --> 00:03:56,820
we started doing VLSM and CIDR.

82
00:03:56,820 --> 00:04:00,065
And so EIGRP introduced support for
that, and so did RIPv2.

83
00:04:00,065 --> 00:04:02,555
But the reason I bring it up now is,

84
00:04:02,555 --> 00:04:05,045
even though we don't need to
learn those old protocols.

85
00:04:05,045 --> 00:04:08,315
EIGRP is designed to be
backwards compatible with IGRP.

86
00:04:08,315 --> 00:04:08,845
>> Right.

87
00:04:08,845 --> 00:04:15,025
>> And so in many ways, it still
operates like a classful protocol.

88
00:04:15,025 --> 00:04:18,890
Now it is classless,
it does support VLSM insider.

89
00:04:18,890 --> 00:04:20,900
But its default activities,

90
00:04:20,900 --> 00:04:23,320
a lot of time will reflect
those old classical boundaries.

91
00:04:23,320 --> 00:04:25,340
And we'll see that during the show.

92
00:04:25,340 --> 00:04:30,050
As we do things with EIGRP, it will
have the same support OSPF does, but

93
00:04:30,050 --> 00:04:34,160
the defaults might make it look a little
more limited until we tweak it a bit and

94
00:04:34,160 --> 00:04:35,210
get it set up.

95
00:04:35,210 --> 00:04:39,410
And properly configured, I will tell
you right now, and I'll go on record.

96
00:04:39,410 --> 00:04:41,230
You can document this.

97
00:04:41,230 --> 00:04:46,410
EIGRP makes better and faster decisions,

98
00:04:46,410 --> 00:04:52,800
while incurring less processor load and
memory load on a router than OSPF, right?

99
00:04:52,800 --> 00:04:56,790
So EIGRP is a better protocol than OSPF,
right?

100
00:04:56,790 --> 00:05:01,210
But OSPF is the most common enterprise
routing protocol in the world.

101
00:05:01,210 --> 00:05:03,300
>> Yeah.
So if EIGRP is better,

102
00:05:03,300 --> 00:05:07,030
if somebody like me is willing got go
on record and say it's better, and

103
00:05:07,030 --> 00:05:10,840
then I say [LAUGH] well yeah, but
everywhere I've worked I've done OSPF.

104
00:05:10,840 --> 00:05:13,080
All right?
You might say wait a minute Don,

105
00:05:13,080 --> 00:05:13,650
what's going on here.

106
00:05:13,650 --> 00:05:15,795
Why are you saying one is better,
but you always run the other.

107
00:05:15,795 --> 00:05:16,750
All right?

108
00:05:16,750 --> 00:05:22,000
The main reason EIGRP is not sweeping
the world is that it is SICO proprietary.

109
00:05:22,000 --> 00:05:24,210
It is their own protocol.

110
00:05:24,210 --> 00:05:25,450
Their own algorithm.

111
00:05:25,450 --> 00:05:26,680
They created it.

112
00:05:26,680 --> 00:05:30,240
And if you want to run EIGRP
on third party equipment.

113
00:05:30,240 --> 00:05:31,300
>> You can.
>> The third party,

114
00:05:31,300 --> 00:05:33,500
they have to license it from Cisco.

115
00:05:33,500 --> 00:05:34,700
>> Yeah.
>> And for a long time day wouldn't do

116
00:05:34,700 --> 00:05:35,690
that, and now they do.

117
00:05:35,690 --> 00:05:37,480
You can license it, but nobody's doing it.

118
00:05:37,480 --> 00:05:38,470
They just say, well forget it,

119
00:05:38,470 --> 00:05:42,235
we'll just do it OSPF instead, and
that's why OSPF is more popular.

120
00:05:42,235 --> 00:05:46,145
And even from me,
where I say, I love EIGRP.

121
00:05:46,145 --> 00:05:51,930
But at the bank I used to work at,
we had CISCO routers.

122
00:05:51,930 --> 00:05:53,670
And we had Juniper firewalls.

123
00:05:53,670 --> 00:05:56,290
>> And
the Juniper firewalls couldn't run EIGRP.

124
00:05:56,290 --> 00:05:59,720
They ran OSPF, well, so
did the Cisco routers.

125
00:05:59,720 --> 00:06:01,140
So we switched to OSPF.

126
00:06:01,140 --> 00:06:03,650
And OSPF has all the features we need.

127
00:06:03,650 --> 00:06:07,711
But it has a little bit more memory
requirement, a little more CPU load.

128
00:06:07,711 --> 00:06:08,795
And it's a little bit slower.

129
00:06:08,795 --> 00:06:10,203
Now, when I say slow,

130
00:06:10,203 --> 00:06:15,336
we're talking about the difference between
half a second and one to two seconds.

131
00:06:15,336 --> 00:06:16,170
>> Yeah.

132
00:06:16,170 --> 00:06:18,750
>> So it's a very,
very small window of time,

133
00:06:18,750 --> 00:06:22,670
usually the equivalent of
one ping is what gets lost.

134
00:06:22,670 --> 00:06:26,640
But it is there, and in a critical
network, that may be a big deal.

135
00:06:26,640 --> 00:06:30,460
>> Yeah and speaking of that in terms
of performance and everything else,

136
00:06:30,460 --> 00:06:34,100
the other advantage of EIRGP that we
also have, is that they declare it.

137
00:06:34,100 --> 00:06:39,100
EIGRP declares that it is
a hundred percent loop free.

138
00:06:39,100 --> 00:06:43,670
So even though it's basis comes off of
a distance vector protocol like IGRP,

139
00:06:43,670 --> 00:06:49,460
EIGRP says hey, we fixed that and not only
can we say that it's gonna handle loops,

140
00:06:49,460 --> 00:06:51,370
we're saying it's one
hundred percent loop free.

141
00:06:51,370 --> 00:06:53,830
>> Yep.
>> That's a pretty impressive claim Don.

142
00:06:53,830 --> 00:06:59,310
>> OSPF is fairly loop free also and
the way it does it is

143
00:06:59,310 --> 00:07:04,880
one router in an OSPF autonomous system,
or even just in an area,

144
00:07:04,880 --> 00:07:09,510
will know about all the other
routers in that area.

145
00:07:09,510 --> 00:07:13,370
If you've got single area OSPF, which is
what we covered, then that's all you have.

146
00:07:13,370 --> 00:07:16,970
So, one router will know about all the
other routers in that autonomous system.

147
00:07:16,970 --> 00:07:19,660
Well, that means you gotta
maintain a pretty big data base.

148
00:07:19,660 --> 00:07:21,460
>> Right.
>> Of all those routers out there and

149
00:07:21,460 --> 00:07:24,550
of all the routes that are there and
what's being networked and advertised.

150
00:07:24,550 --> 00:07:27,063
And so when they run the OSPF or
the SPF algorithms,

151
00:07:27,063 --> 00:07:30,294
they can figure out where there's
loops and [INAUDIBLE] them out.

152
00:07:30,294 --> 00:07:31,050
Right?

153
00:07:31,050 --> 00:07:35,730
Well EIGRP is a distance vector protocol.

154
00:07:35,730 --> 00:07:38,240
It's not link state like OSPF,
its distance vector.

155
00:07:38,240 --> 00:07:41,895
And that means your router is only
talking directly to its neighbors.

156
00:07:41,895 --> 00:07:42,730
>> Mm-hm.
>> Other routers it's

157
00:07:42,730 --> 00:07:43,580
directly connected to.

158
00:07:43,580 --> 00:07:46,560
It doesn't know all the routers
through the network.

159
00:07:46,560 --> 00:07:49,660
So your first thought might be well if
it doesn't know all the routers that

160
00:07:49,660 --> 00:07:51,695
are out there, we might have loops.

161
00:07:51,695 --> 00:07:53,130
>> Mm-hm.

162
00:07:53,130 --> 00:07:55,858
There's a few things that come
into play to prevent them, and

163
00:07:55,858 --> 00:07:59,435
I know we covered these in other episodes
so I'm just going to mention them here.

164
00:07:59,435 --> 00:08:06,922
We talked about poison reverse,
split horizon, and.

165
00:08:06,922 --> 00:08:09,072
Shoot, maximum metrics.

166
00:08:09,072 --> 00:08:11,310
The whole count to infinity thing.

167
00:08:11,310 --> 00:08:16,770
Those are features that are built into
Cisco routers that accent EIGRP and

168
00:08:16,770 --> 00:08:19,170
help it to stop loops before they occur.

169
00:08:19,170 --> 00:08:21,870
And then there's something called
a feasibility calculation.

170
00:08:21,870 --> 00:08:25,670
Now, I don't wanna get into that just yet,
cuz if you just learned what EIGRP

171
00:08:25,670 --> 00:08:30,090
was in the last five minutes, feasibility
calculations are kind of out there.

172
00:08:30,090 --> 00:08:34,040
So, let's hold off on that concept for
later in the episode.

173
00:08:34,040 --> 00:08:37,590
But there's a mathematical operation
they run where they can calculate loops.

174
00:08:37,590 --> 00:08:42,280
Now, it does mean that occasionally
EIGRP blocks a real route

175
00:08:42,280 --> 00:08:45,818
because it might be a loop, so it can
make a mistake whereas OSPF doesn't.

176
00:08:45,818 --> 00:08:49,272
But the trade off is you get
much better performance and

177
00:08:49,272 --> 00:08:52,890
faster decisions and
a 100% loop free environment.

178
00:08:52,890 --> 00:08:55,510
You actually cannot
create a loop in EIGRP.

179
00:08:55,510 --> 00:08:56,810
>> Yeah.

180
00:08:56,810 --> 00:09:00,970
The other thing that we also have
with EIGRP is the idea here that,

181
00:09:00,970 --> 00:09:01,870
like OSPF here.

182
00:09:01,870 --> 00:09:04,790
I know we're comparing a lot against OSPF,
but that's really a direct comparison for

183
00:09:04,790 --> 00:09:09,600
us, is that OSPF was really
designed around the IP protocol.

184
00:09:09,600 --> 00:09:13,600
EIGRP though, it doesn't really care
what ticker protocol you run so

185
00:09:13,600 --> 00:09:17,590
if you wanted to you could run IP,
you could run IP version six,

186
00:09:17,590 --> 00:09:20,570
you could even choose, Don,
if you wanted to run Apple talk.

187
00:09:20,570 --> 00:09:21,383
I don't know if you would.

188
00:09:21,383 --> 00:09:21,951
>> You can.

189
00:09:21,951 --> 00:09:23,760
>> Or IPXSPX here.

190
00:09:23,760 --> 00:09:28,350
And so in that particular advantage here,
EIGRP was really designed at the beginning

191
00:09:28,350 --> 00:09:30,990
to say hey we'll support anything
that's actually out there.

192
00:09:30,990 --> 00:09:34,280
And they are simply just replacing
the addressing component of it,

193
00:09:34,280 --> 00:09:39,900
with a different component like Appletalk
or IPXSPS, or whatever else is out there.

194
00:09:39,900 --> 00:09:43,730
So we had mentioned this before, we might
have mentioned it in the OSPF episode,

195
00:09:43,730 --> 00:09:45,250
for all I know.

196
00:09:45,250 --> 00:09:48,740
That OSPF had to be written
from the ground up.

197
00:09:48,740 --> 00:09:51,630
Okay, rewritten when they
supported IP version six.

198
00:09:51,630 --> 00:09:56,050
When EIGRP, they simply added in
the IPV 6 module and it's ready to go.

199
00:09:56,050 --> 00:09:57,950
So it made it a very flexible protocol.

200
00:09:57,950 --> 00:09:59,450
>> And module that's the keyword.

201
00:09:59,450 --> 00:10:01,020
>> Yeah.
>> You want to remember for the exam.

202
00:10:01,020 --> 00:10:03,960
The EIGRP protocol is a modular.

203
00:10:03,960 --> 00:10:08,320
Cisco designed it where you have
the logic engine, the formula, and

204
00:10:08,320 --> 00:10:10,920
then you have modules for
each of the protocols so

205
00:10:10,920 --> 00:10:13,410
when a new protocol comes out,
Cisco just writes a new module.

206
00:10:13,410 --> 00:10:18,139
So there's an IPV four module,
IPV six, what are the other one?

207
00:10:18,139 --> 00:10:20,233
There's Apple talk, IPXSPX,

208
00:10:20,233 --> 00:10:24,500
there is a decknet module
there's a couple of other ones.

209
00:10:24,500 --> 00:10:27,640
If it's a routable protocol,
the odds are Cisco's written a module.

210
00:10:27,640 --> 00:10:30,110
If it's netbuoy, it's nonroutable.

211
00:10:30,110 --> 00:10:31,260
Cisco's not gonna write a module.

212
00:10:31,260 --> 00:10:32,750
But most of the other
ones they've done it.

213
00:10:32,750 --> 00:10:34,520
So, very cool that it does that,

214
00:10:34,520 --> 00:10:37,800
and it was one of the first
routing protocols to support IPv6.

215
00:10:37,800 --> 00:10:41,500
I think ISIS was the first one.

216
00:10:41,500 --> 00:10:45,390
But OSPF, they have to rewrite that from
scratch every time they want to support

217
00:10:45,390 --> 00:10:47,280
a new protocol, so it is a big deal.

218
00:10:48,780 --> 00:10:50,750
All right, and so
kind of keep that in mind.

219
00:10:50,750 --> 00:10:54,220
That's another kind of bell and
whistle that EIGRP has.

220
00:10:54,220 --> 00:10:57,990
So there are a few other neat things that,
you know,

221

00:01:21,300 --> 00:01:26,300

>> I got all diagram
happy before the show.

34

35
00:01:57,880 --> 00:02:00,770
This is a typical network
that we tend to have.

36
00:02:00,770 --> 00:02:04,510
Over on the left hand side, you have a

00:02:04,510 --> 00:02:08,120

our router one is representing that,

38
00:02:08,120 --> 00:02:11,990

course, the rest of the internet here.

39
00:02:11,990 --> 00:02:13,080
So usually, that's what we have.

40
00:02:13,080 --> 00:02:15,790
But the problem that we have though,
is that hey,

00:02:15,790 --> 00:02:20,650
what happens if something is bad

00:02:20,650 --> 00:02:22,590
And I have to fix that right away.

43
00:02:23,630 --> 00:02:25,050
>> Yeah, router one in this scenario.

44
00:02:25,050 --> 00:02:27,560
And this is a very, very common scenario.

45
00:02:27,560 --> 00:02:30,720
This is what a lot of home networks
are like, your small businesses.

46
00:02:30,720 --> 00:02:32,450
Router one is a single point of failure.

47
00:02:32,450 --> 00:02:34,960
If it fails, the network fails.

48
00:02:34,960 --> 00:02:36,010
>> Yeah.
>> Your internal people

49
00:02:36,010 --> 00:02:38,400
can't get out to the internet and
that's the end of it.

50
00:02:38,400 --> 00:02:40,210
So what is our solution?

51
00:02:40,210 --> 00:02:44,090
Well you can buy more expensive equipment,
you can do things like that to try and

00:02:44,090 --> 00:02:45,740

53
00:02:45,740 --> 00:02:49,080
But the best solution is
to get a second router.

54
00:02:49,080 --> 00:02:50,520
And if we're going to
get a second a router,

55
00:02:50,520 --> 00:02:54,380
we might as well go the big step and
get a second ISP also.

56
00:02:54,380 --> 00:02:57,820
We might have a DSL and
a cable line or something.

57
00:02:57,820 --> 00:03:00,400
>> The problem that we still
have with just even this

58
00:03:00,400 --> 00:03:02,840
set up is not only that
single point of failure, but

59
00:03:02,840 --> 00:03:06,680
remember that every device that needs to
connect out to the internet, to Amazon.com

60
00:03:06,680 --> 00:03:10,920
in our example here, they're gonna be
configured with that one default gateway.

61
00:03:11,920 --> 00:03:13,180
So even if this fails and

62
00:03:13,180 --> 00:03:17,310
I have two particular routers, I would
normally have to actually go in and

63
00:03:17,310 --> 00:03:20,940
reconfigure my default gateways for
every single device as well.

64
00:03:20,940 --> 00:03:24,110
So there's a lot of what we call
administrative effort involved

65
00:03:24,110 --> 00:03:26,260
even in just adding in redundancies.

66
00:03:26,260 --> 00:03:28,940
We're talking about as another way to
actually help us do this much more

67
00:03:28,940 --> 00:03:30,580
efficiently as well.

68
00:03:30,580 --> 00:03:33,270
>> Yeah, so using Ronnie's example there,
let's say we went out and

69
00:03:33,270 --> 00:03:35,790
we bought a second router,
and we got a second ISP, and

70
00:03:35,790 --> 00:03:39,270
you don't have to have a second ISP, but
I just did it for completeness here.

71
00:03:39,270 --> 00:03:43,130
So maybe I've got Router 1,
which is connected to a T1 line.

72
00:03:44,170 --> 00:03:47,879
And so
it's got an internal IP of 192.168.0.1 and

73
00:03:47,879 --> 00:03:51,456
I set my internal guys to use
that as their default gateway.

74
00:03:51,456 --> 00:03:53,407
So when they go out to the internet,

75
00:03:53,407 --> 00:03:56,370
they're passing through
Router 1 on their way out.

76
00:03:56,370 --> 00:04:00,260
Then, I bring in Router 2
connected to a cable modem or

77
00:04:00,260 --> 00:04:03,650
some other type of broadband connection.

78
00:04:03,650 --> 00:04:08,080
And I give it an internal
IP of 192.168.0.2.

79
00:04:08,080 --> 00:04:12,570
Well, on my host on the inside,
if I set their gateway to .1,

80
00:04:12,570 --> 00:04:15,450
they're going out router one and
everything's happy.

81
00:04:15,450 --> 00:04:20,500
But if that router were to fail,
if that router goes offline.

82
00:04:20,500 --> 00:04:23,290
We've got this other pathway over here.

83
00:04:23,290 --> 00:04:27,792
This path that's still
up that we could use but

84
00:04:27,792 --> 00:04:30,120
our PCs aren't gonna use it are they?

85
00:04:30,120 --> 00:04:35,520
They're not gonna use it because their
default gateway is still set to .1 and

86
00:04:35,520 --> 00:04:37,930
this router down here is .2.

87
00:04:37,930 --> 00:04:41,340
They're not set to use it I would
have to do just like Ronny said.

88
00:04:41,340 --> 00:04:44,410
Go to each of my computers,
change their default gateway and

89
00:04:44,410 --> 00:04:46,370
map it over to this other side.

90
00:04:46,370 --> 00:04:49,560
If you have a lot of computers,
it's not really an option, and

91
00:04:49,560 --> 00:04:50,530
it's just time consuming.

92
00:04:52,620 --> 00:04:58,130
So what would be better is if we have some
way to make it automatically failure over.

93
00:04:58,130 --> 00:05:02,170
Are our PC manufacturers, or
operating system manufacturers,

94
00:05:02,170 --> 00:05:04,870
like Microsoft and Apple and stuff.

95
00:05:04,870 --> 00:05:06,660
They could solve this problem for

96
00:05:06,660 --> 00:05:10,180
us by allowing us to put in more than
one default gateway, and in IPV6,

97
00:05:10,180 --> 00:05:13,950
this is something that happens,
but in IPV4, they usually don't.

98
00:05:15,760 --> 00:05:20,880
Linux, Windows, OSX, out of the box they
really only support one default gateway.

99
00:05:20,880 --> 00:05:23,920
And so it does require a manual change.

100
00:05:23,920 --> 00:05:25,540
So what Cisco did,

101
00:05:25,540 --> 00:05:29,670
is Cisco said there's got to be some way
we can help with this on the router side.

102
00:05:29,670 --> 00:05:34,660
How can we make it where
the routers provide a single IP,

103
00:05:34,660 --> 00:05:38,530
or some method that will make the host
switch over when there's a failure.

104
00:05:38,530 --> 00:05:41,280
>> And this is where we come into that
topic that we were just mentioning.

105
00:05:41,280 --> 00:05:45,030
The idea that we call
First Hop Redundancy Protocol and for

106
00:05:45,030 --> 00:05:49,640
us there's actually three different
major protocols that are actually used

107
00:05:49,640 --> 00:05:51,380
when we start addressing this.

108
00:05:51,380 --> 00:05:55,530
In doing this, what we actually end up
doing is that we set a default gateway

109
00:05:55,530 --> 00:05:59,680
that really doesn't exist, but
it's recognized by our different routers

110
00:05:59,680 --> 00:06:02,800
that will help us instead and
that's what we're about to do.

111
00:06:02,800 --> 00:06:06,980
>> So let's start with the first one which
is the most likely one to be on the exam.

112
00:06:06,980 --> 00:06:11,150
Cisco came up with their own
proprietary protocol to achieve this.

113
00:06:11,150 --> 00:06:13,500
They created what is HSRP or

114
00:06:13,500 --> 00:06:19,310
the hot standby redundancy protocol or
Hunts Standby router Redundancy Protocol,

115
00:06:19,310 --> 00:06:21,100
that little router bit
normally gets left off.

116
00:06:21,100 --> 00:06:26,640
But anyhow it's HSRP and what it does
is it takes these two routers and

117

00:37:57,600 --> 00:38:01,420

00:38:02,450 --> 00:38:05,820

00:38:05,820 --> 00:38:12,330

00:38:12,330 --> 00:38:17,100

00:38:17,100 --> 00:38:20,920

00:38:20,920 --> 00:38:23,198

both, and everybody gets routed through.

00:38:38,690 --> 00:38:42,790

00:38:42,790 --> 00:38:46,860
Where the clients use the MAC addresses

00:38:46,860 --> 00:38:52,560

00:48:22,740 --> 00:48:25,640

00:48:25,640 --> 00:48:28,240

00:48:28,240 --> 00:48:31,540
It's just not a realistic thing

943
00:48:31,540 --> 00:48:36,040

replace our need for a sniffer.

944
00:48:36,040 --> 00:48:40,820
Instead of reporting to us the actual
traffic, the actual packets.

945
00:48:40,820 --> 00:48:44,250

reports to us a description,

00:48:44,250 --> 00:48:49,270
it says this IP went to that
IP using this protocol, right.

947
00:48:49,270 --> 00:48:52,380
The stuff that we would normally find
in the header of a packet anyway, but

948
00:48:52,380 --> 00:48:55,490
it leaves the payload data off, all right.

949
00:48:55,490 --> 00:48:58,880
So it's reporting to us
the information that we really want,

950
00:48:58,880 --> 00:49:03,260
it's much more efficient,
much more smaller sets of data and

00:49:03,260 --> 00:49:07,020
that means we can leave it running
24 hours a day, months on end.

00:49:07,020 --> 00:49:11,760

an overwhelming amount of information.

00:49:11,760 --> 00:49:15,020

00:49:19,070 --> 00:49:22,000

this stuff, we wanna make sure that

everything that we need to, and

38

And so we're going to be

39

in making sure that we cover things like
Spanning Tree again, and showing you,

40

demonstrating that, and especially Router
