00:02:12,400 --> 00:02:14,260
>> Yeah, good stuff.

42
00:02:14,260 --> 00:02:16,800
So let's just dive right into it and

43
00:02:16,800 --> 00:02:20,940
the first thing we're gonna tackle
is taking a look at trunking, right?

44
00:02:20,940 --> 00:02:22,970
Trunking between Cisco switches.

45
00:02:22,970 --> 00:02:27,010
Pretty much every Cisco switch
that you can telnet or SSH into.

46
00:02:27,010 --> 00:02:30,840
If it's got a management interface,
it will typically support trunking and

47
00:02:30,840 --> 00:02:35,520
so, if you've got more than one
VLAN on your network, and you

48
00:02:35,520 --> 00:02:40,390
want to spread that VLAN across switches,
you need a trunk link between them.

49
00:02:40,390 --> 00:02:41,720
And we did a whole trunking episode and

50
00:02:41,720 --> 00:02:43,320
we talked about how to set those up and
stuff.

51
00:02:43,320 --> 00:02:45,210
But let's take some switches here.

52
00:02:45,210 --> 00:02:48,360
The switches behind me,
they're Cisco 3560s.

53
00:02:48,360 --> 00:02:51,570
And they are the switches
that are on the exam.

54
00:02:51,570 --> 00:02:55,240
So it's what you're gonna
see in the actual exam.

55
00:02:55,240 --> 00:03:01,440
And basically, they support switching,
they actually support dynamic switching or

56
00:03:01,440 --> 00:03:05,540
dynamic trunking which means we don't
even have to tell them to trunk.

57
00:03:05,540 --> 00:03:07,580
They'll just do it.

58
00:03:07,580 --> 00:03:10,450
And that's kind of cool, right?

59
00:03:10,450 --> 00:03:13,110
But it doesn't always work
the way that we expect to.

60
00:03:13,110 --> 00:03:15,280
So let's take a look at an example here.

61
00:03:15,280 --> 00:03:21,090
I've got these two 3560s and
I've got two just crossover cables run so

62
00:03:21,090 --> 00:03:24,300
that port one on one switch is plugged
into port one on the other one.

63
00:03:24,300 --> 00:03:27,640
And port two on one switch is plugged
into port two on the other one.

64
00:03:27,640 --> 00:03:30,570
I just plugged in the cables,
they're crossovers, and so

65
00:03:30,570 --> 00:03:35,400
in theory, I should be trunking
on those interfaces, right.

66
00:03:35,400 --> 00:03:38,360
>> So remember that you may also
end up running into some different

67
00:03:39,560 --> 00:03:41,910
default types of things that go on.

68
00:03:41,910 --> 00:03:45,040
For example, Don and I were talking
right before the show, such as

69
00:03:45,040 --> 00:03:48,910
the example that we were talking about
here that ports can actually be set for

70
00:03:48,910 --> 00:03:51,310
trunking here using
Dynamic Trunking Protocol.

71
00:03:51,310 --> 00:03:52,920
Some are set with what
are called desirable and

72
00:03:52,920 --> 00:03:54,950
some are set with what we call auto.

73
00:03:54,950 --> 00:03:58,530
And they are different, and so
you may actually get some weird, different

74
00:03:58,530 --> 00:04:02,510
configurations if you don't actually set
them up both correctly on both ends.

75
00:04:02,510 --> 00:04:03,770
So I wanna make sure that we go over that.

76
00:04:03,770 --> 00:04:06,090
>> Yeah, so
let's take a look at these switches.

77
00:04:06,090 --> 00:04:10,492
So if I take a look at one of the
interfaces, like if I do a show interface

78
00:04:10,492 --> 00:04:15,760
fa0/1 trunk, that says show me
the trunking information about port fa0/1.

79
00:04:15,760 --> 00:04:22,060
And when I look at it, I can see that
its encapsulation is set to negotiate.

80
00:04:22,060 --> 00:04:25,090
So that means that it will support ISL,
the inner switch link.

81
00:04:25,090 --> 00:04:30,940
That's the proprietary Cisco trunking,
as well as 802.1q VLAN tagging, right.

82
00:04:30,940 --> 00:04:35,280
So the nicer, more common,
open standard supported trunking.

83
00:04:35,280 --> 00:04:37,280
Right, so it'll support both.

84
00:04:37,280 --> 00:04:39,470
And it's mode is set to auto.

85
00:04:39,470 --> 00:04:43,190
It will automatically trunk given
the opportunity, all right.

86
00:04:43,190 --> 00:04:48,570
But I can see that it is
currently not trunking.

87
00:04:48,570 --> 00:04:50,530
All right, and
that's on switch one, fa0/1.

88
00:04:50,530 --> 00:04:55,140
If I look at fa0/2,
I can see the same thing.

89
00:04:55,140 --> 00:04:57,820
Auto, negotiate, not-trunking.

90
00:04:57,820 --> 00:05:03,070
And if I look at the other
side of the equation, so

91
00:05:03,070 --> 00:05:04,670
I'm looking over on switch two.

92
00:05:06,620 --> 00:05:08,740
I can see the same exact thing.

93
00:05:08,740 --> 00:05:13,350
The mode is auto, negotiation for
the encapsulation and not-trunking.

94
00:05:13,350 --> 00:05:13,880
All right?

95
00:05:13,880 --> 00:05:16,060
So if they're set to automatic and

96
00:05:16,060 --> 00:05:20,020
I plug a cable into the two,
they're the same switch.

97
00:05:20,020 --> 00:05:21,440
>> Yeah.
>> They're both 3560s,

98
00:05:21,440 --> 00:05:23,060
why the heck is it not trunking?

99
00:05:23,060 --> 00:05:24,020
>> Yeah.
And also,

100
00:05:24,020 --> 00:05:28,850
in this situation here, when we're using
dynamic trunking protocol, automatic says,

101
00:05:28,850 --> 00:05:32,070
hey, I'll do whatever
the other side is doing.

102
00:05:32,070 --> 00:05:33,480
Well, if the other side
is saying same thing,

103
00:05:33,480 --> 00:05:36,320
hey, I'll do whatever
the other side is doing,

104
00:05:36,320 --> 00:05:39,500
it's sort of like us trying to decide
where we're gonna go to lunch, right?

105
00:05:39,500 --> 00:05:42,700
Nobody actually ever says, hey,
this is where we want to go.

106
00:05:42,700 --> 00:05:44,810
And, so they both kinda just sit there.

107
00:05:44,810 --> 00:05:49,030
And they wait for one side to actually
say this is what I want to do.

108
00:05:49,030 --> 00:05:52,740
So you have both sides set to auto,
you're probably not gonna end up trunking.

109
00:05:52,740 --> 00:05:53,240
>> Yeah.

110
00:05:53,240 --> 00:05:57,040
In that automatic mode they're
fully willing to become a trunk

111
00:05:57,040 --> 00:05:58,575
if somebody else asks them.

112
00:05:58,575 --> 00:06:01,310
>> [LAUGH]
>> But if nobody asks, if nobody initiates

113
00:06:01,310 --> 00:06:03,912
it's not gonna trunk and
that's exactly what we have right here.

114
00:06:03,912 --> 00:06:04,740
All right?

115
00:06:04,740 --> 00:06:09,110
Now Ronnie mentioned a really valid
point which was, with the 3550s,

116
00:06:09,110 --> 00:06:11,862
that's the switches that were
released prior to this one.

117
00:06:11,862 --> 00:06:16,710
The 3550s,
they were set to desirable by default.

118
00:06:16,710 --> 00:06:17,270
Right?

119
00:06:17,270 --> 00:06:21,370
So with negotiation like this you really
got three modes that you can be in.

120
00:06:21,370 --> 00:06:22,440
One, it can be disabled.

121
00:06:22,440 --> 00:06:24,440
You can disable dynamic
trunking altogether.

122
00:06:24,440 --> 00:06:26,360
That's what I like to do.

123
00:06:26,360 --> 00:06:29,510
Or you can set it to auto,
which says we'll become a trunk

124
00:06:29,510 --> 00:06:33,780
if the other side asks us, or you can
go desirable, which says we will ask,

125
00:06:33,780 --> 00:06:36,230
we will try to become a trunk, all right?

126
00:06:36,230 --> 00:06:42,800
So if I take two 3550s and I plug
a cable in like this, they will trunk.

127
00:06:42,800 --> 00:06:48,790
And if I take a 3550, and
I plug it into a 3560, they will trunk.

128
00:06:48,790 --> 00:06:54,340
But if I take two 3560s and I put them
together, well, they won't trunk.

129
00:06:54,340 --> 00:06:56,180
They're both set to Auto.

130
00:06:56,180 --> 00:06:59,070
And, so this is one of those
weird situations where you need

131
00:06:59,070 --> 00:07:01,890
to understand your platform, understand
the switches you're working on, and

132
00:07:01,890 --> 00:07:05,310
understand that the defaults
are different from platform to platform.

133
00:07:05,310 --> 00:07:09,130
And this show command is actually
the greatest place for you to start.

134
00:07:09,130 --> 00:07:12,500
If you're not getting trunking on the link
that you're supposed to be getting,

135
00:07:12,500 --> 00:07:14,710
check both sides, check the mode.

01:16:17,323 --> 01:16:19,620
I should be able to ping
both of them this time.

1420
01:16:22,080 --> 01:16:23,410
If I can spell ping
>> [LAUGH]

1421
01:16:23,410 --> 01:16:24,740
>> It's a challenge from day one.

1422
01:16:24,740 --> 01:16:25,420
>> There you go.

1423
01:16:25,420 --> 01:16:27,270
>> Now, I've got sequential communication.

1424
01:16:27,270 --> 01:16:28,305
So just be aware of that.

1425
01:16:28,305 --> 01:16:30,430
Now, just because you turned
auto-summary off doesn't mean

01:16:30,430 --> 01:16:31,480

01:16:35,530 --> 01:16:39,550

1429
01:16:39,550 --> 01:16:42,970

1430
01:16:42,970 --> 01:16:47,250

1431
01:16:47,250 --> 01:16:49,270

1432
01:16:49,270 --> 01:16:54,600

1433
01:16:54,600 --> 01:16:55,240

1444
01:17:22,550 --> 01:17:23,510
authentication right.

1445
01:17:23,510 --> 01:17:27,540
EIGRP supports doing MD5 hashes
to verify the identity of

1446
01:17:27,540 --> 01:17:28,420
the neighbor on the other end.

1447
01:17:29,580 --> 01:17:32,210
I find that you don't really
need that in production though,

1448
01:17:32,210 --> 01:17:35,340

using passive interfaces,

1449
01:17:35,340 --> 01:17:39,000

attacker can introduce their own router.

1450
01:17:39,000 --> 01:17:43,190
But if for some reason you have to
use the IGRP on a shared network,

1451
01:17:43,190 --> 01:17:46,120
then having that authentication

1452
01:17:46,120 --> 01:17:47,680
Then there's,

1453

1454
01:17:50,850 --> 01:17:54,290

that's really the basics of EIGRP.

1455
01:17:54,290 --> 01:17:56,680
Great protocol, easily better than OSPF.

1456
01:17:56,680 --> 01:17:58,430
Makes better decisions, but

1457
01:17:58,430 --> 01:18:00,480
it's proprietary nature is
what holds it back right.

1458
01:18:00,480 --> 01:18:01,120
It's CISCO only.

functionality.

45
00:02:20,750 --> 00:02:23,580
Let's just start real broad.

46
00:02:23,580 --> 00:02:26,910
What is a WAN technology?

47
00:02:26,910 --> 00:02:30,900
Any time we're connecting two areas
that are geographically separated.

48
00:02:32,120 --> 00:02:36,530
If I've got an office in one city and
an office in a neighboring city,

49
00:02:36,530 --> 00:02:39,580
I probably can't run my own
cable between those two offices.

50
00:02:39,580 --> 00:02:40,900
They are different cities.

51
00:02:40,900 --> 00:02:44,490
I had to cross a lot of government and
private land.

52
00:02:44,490 --> 00:02:48,770
So instead I'm gonna lease a connection
from, usually a telephone company,

53
00:02:48,770 --> 00:02:49,740
right, a telco.

54
00:02:49,740 --> 00:02:54,190
I'm gonna lease that line and
pay a monthly fee or annual fee or

55
00:02:54,190 --> 00:02:55,420
whatever, to use it.

56
00:02:55,420 --> 00:02:57,650
Those are wide area network connections.

57
00:02:57,650 --> 00:03:01,040
WANs are basically networks that we rent,
right, that we don't own,

58
00:03:01,040 --> 00:03:02,990
we don't control, somebody else does.

59
00:03:02,990 --> 00:03:04,540
And we pay for access on it.

60
00:03:04,540 --> 00:03:05,320
>> Yeah.

61
00:03:05,320 --> 00:03:09,910
So in generic terms and
what we're talking about,

62
00:03:09,910 --> 00:03:14,160
LAN technology, what we control,
what we implement, what we setup.

63
00:03:14,160 --> 00:03:18,640
LAN technology, we pay for somebody else's
use of their network and we normally

64
00:03:18,640 --> 00:03:22,770
pay a subscription fee to it monthly or
yearly or however we want to do it, and

65
00:03:22,770 --> 00:03:27,100
that's what ends up happening and
they guarantee for us.

66
00:03:27,100 --> 00:03:29,680
That type of service
through their network.

67
00:03:29,680 --> 00:03:32,250
Now in some of them,
we're gonna actually see where

68
00:03:32,250 --> 00:03:36,340

69
00:03:36,340 --> 00:03:38,410

though, not so much so.

70
00:03:38,410 --> 00:03:40,280
You actually have your
own private connection.

71
00:03:40,280 --> 00:03:42,405
>> Yeah.
And that's the difference between like

72
00:03:42,405 --> 00:03:46,535
a point to point link and a shared link
and so some of these technologies can be

73

implemented in more than one way and
we just need to be aware of that right.

74
00:03:49,605 --> 00:03:52,255
So Ronnie let's run down the list
here of each of these and

75

then there's some of them we're
going to spend more time on.

76
00:03:54,785 --> 00:03:55,805
And so we'll tackle those.

77
00:03:55,805 --> 00:03:59,215

overview of the 10 day list.

78
00:03:59,215 --> 00:04:00,695
The first one is one of my favorites.

79
00:04:00,695 --> 00:04:04,590
It's becoming very popular
in the last couple years.

80
00:04:04,590 --> 00:04:07,110
But it's the metro ethernet, right.

81
00:04:07,110 --> 00:04:11,620
Metro ethernet means that it's
traditional Ethernet networking.

82
00:04:11,620 --> 00:04:14,710
It might be fiber,
it might be copper, whatever.

83
00:04:14,710 --> 00:04:17,270
But it's being run through
a metropolitan area,

84
00:04:17,270 --> 00:04:21,000
usually between facilities
in the same city, all right.

85
00:04:21,000 --> 00:04:25,310
And a good example is right here,
our building.

86
00:04:25,310 --> 00:04:28,350
Our Internet connection here,
we have a 40 megabit Internet connection.

87
00:04:28,350 --> 00:04:31,460
Now, 40 megabit may not sound like a lot,

88
00:04:31,460 --> 00:04:34,670
if you've got a cable modem that's
got 40 megabit or whatever.

89
00:04:34,670 --> 00:04:37,500
But ours is a fiber-optic connection
that runs into the building and

90
00:04:37,500 --> 00:04:38,810
it's a dedicated connection.

91
00:04:38,810 --> 00:04:41,650
So we have 40 megabit up and
40 megabit down, so

92
00:04:41,650 --> 00:04:44,080
our download and
upload speeds are the same.

93
00:04:44,080 --> 00:04:47,985
That fiber connection runs from
us all the way back to our

94
00:04:47,985 --> 00:04:52,510
ISP that's about eight miles away or
something.

95
00:04:52,510 --> 00:04:53,960
So about eight miles away, so

96
00:04:53,960 --> 00:04:58,070
it's a pretty long stretch of fiber now
we didn't run that fiber right they did.

97
00:04:58,070 --> 00:05:01,760
And they ran it at some point, usually
they run like a loop around the city and

98
00:05:01,760 --> 00:05:03,590
we're just tapping into that loop.

99
00:05:03,590 --> 00:05:07,710
Well, we pay for that access, and
they provide us a high speed connection.

100
00:05:07,710 --> 00:05:09,870
Now, before we had metro Ethernet,

101
00:05:09,870 --> 00:05:13,680
we were using T1 lines,
which are number 5 down here, T1's.

102
00:05:13,680 --> 00:05:18,010
In the United States,
a T1 is a copper-based serial connection.

103
00:05:18,010 --> 00:05:20,600
It's run over your digital phone networks.

104
00:05:20,600 --> 00:05:23,740
And it provides 1.5 megabit of bandwidth,
right?

105
00:05:23,740 --> 00:05:27,260
Now, 1.5 megabit is not
a lot of bandwidth today.

106
00:05:27,260 --> 00:05:29,400
It was ten years ago, but not today.

107
00:05:29,400 --> 00:05:32,940
And so we're constantly striving
to get higher bandwidth.

108
00:05:32,940 --> 00:05:35,710
Metro ethernet networks
will typically provide you

109
00:05:35,710 --> 00:05:38,090
the highest bandwidth possible, right.

110
00:05:38,090 --> 00:05:39,635
Some areas can get as much as a gigabit.

111
00:05:39,635 --> 00:05:41,030
>> Mm-hm.

112
00:05:41,030 --> 00:05:45,160
Yeah, the differences in those two early
technologies that we want to make sure

113
00:05:45,160 --> 00:05:48,540
that we're aware of here,
is that when we talk about T1 lines,

114
00:05:48,540 --> 00:05:53,280
we're really not concerned about really
IP addresses so much on the T1s.

115
00:05:53,280 --> 00:05:56,410
We're sending from one particular
place to another one, and

116
00:05:56,410 --> 00:05:59,300
because those are the only to connections
that are there, that's all that matters.

117
00:05:59,300 --> 00:06:03,350
But with metro ethernet, we actually do
use IP addresses here to ensure that our

118
00:06:03,350 --> 00:06:06,570
data gets from one particular
location to another one as well.

119
00:06:06,570 --> 00:06:08,110
>> Yeah, I didn't mention that, Ronnie.

120
00:06:08,110 --> 00:06:09,480
>> Yeah.
>> But that's a good point that T1s

121
00:06:09,480 --> 00:06:11,350
are typically point-to-point, right?

122
00:06:11,350 --> 00:06:13,470
>> Mm-hm.
>> So it's normally you on one end and

123
00:06:13,470 --> 00:06:14,470
the Teleco on the other end.

124
00:06:14,470 --> 00:06:15,660
>> Right.
>> Or you on one end and

125
00:06:15,660 --> 00:06:18,260
another one of your
facilities on the other end.

126
00:06:18,260 --> 00:06:21,959
And as a result, you don't need a lot
of technology to make that T1 work,

127
00:06:21,959 --> 00:06:23,825
they're pretty straight forward.

128
00:06:23,825 --> 00:06:27,130
Metro ethernet networks though,
a lot of times that's a shared network,

129
00:06:27,130 --> 00:06:30,670
where you're connected to a network, but
so are other customers that are there.

130
00:06:30,670 --> 00:06:32,430
And that's what it's so
important when you buy them,

131
00:06:32,430 --> 00:06:37,210
that you negotiate out a contract rate, so

132
00:06:37,210 --> 00:06:40,040
we negotiated a 40mbs with our provider,
and we're guaranteed that, we don't

133
00:06:40,040 --> 00:06:44,350
share that with other customers, there's
40 megabits sliced off just for us, right?

134
00:06:44,350 --> 00:06:48,280
So be careful with that some of the other
technologies, if we kinda jump around,

135
00:06:48,280 --> 00:06:51,170
like DSL, and cable, right?

136
00:06:51,170 --> 00:06:58,480
Digital subscriber line which really
comes in over a phone line typically.

137
00:06:58,480 --> 00:07:02,150
You know that one is a shared network
amongst all the other phone customers.

138
00:07:02,150 --> 00:07:06,520
In that area, and then cable, that's
coming over your cable television link,

139
00:07:06,520 --> 00:07:10,020
and again, shared bandwidth with the other
people right there in your community.

140
00:07:10,020 --> 00:07:15,070
So, for those guys you don't have
dedicated assigned bandwidth to yourself,

141
00:07:15,070 --> 00:07:18,310
sharing it, and that means you're
in competition with the 12 year

142
00:07:18,310 --> 00:07:21,850
old next door who's
running 800 bit torrents.

143
00:07:21,850 --> 00:07:26,860
>> And this is a good point for us to make
in terms of the shared network connection.

144
00:07:26,860 --> 00:07:30,910
And the reason for that is because, when
you have that shared network connection,

145
00:07:30,910 --> 00:07:33,300
the easiest way that you
know is actually simple.

146
00:07:33,300 --> 00:07:36,250
You go and download a file early in
the morning that's fairly large.

147
00:07:36,250 --> 00:07:38,810
And you go, wow, I got great speeds.

148
00:07:38,810 --> 00:07:40,570
8 o'clock in the evening
when everybody and

149
00:07:40,570 --> 00:07:44,080
their mother is on checking whatever
their checking on the internet here.

150
00:07:44,080 --> 00:07:45,680
All of a sudden the connection slows and
down,

151
00:07:45,680 --> 00:07:48,230
and that same file download
takes a lot longer.

152
00:07:48,230 --> 00:07:49,810
And that means you are now competing for

153
00:07:49,810 --> 00:07:53,160
access into that particular
network that you have.

154
00:07:53,160 --> 00:07:56,265
Now with cable, that's what you
really have to contend with.

155
00:07:56,265 --> 00:07:58,592
With DSL though we have
to contingents right?

156
00:07:58,592 --> 00:08:02,259
The idea of not only multiple people on
that same particular connection that may

157
00:08:02,259 --> 00:08:04,310
be there, it's the distance, right?

158
00:08:04,310 --> 00:08:06,560
That is actually where we have a lock.

159
00:08:06,560 --> 00:08:09,540
So the closer you are to
that TelCo switch,

160
00:08:09,540 --> 00:08:11,790
the faster you're gonna get with DSL.

161
00:08:11,790 --> 00:08:14,520
The further away you are,
the slower speeds.

162
00:08:14,520 --> 00:08:17,040
And I guarantee you,
if you're at that maximum limit,

163
00:08:17,040 --> 00:08:21,580
you're gonna be kind of struggling to
get connected much faster than somebody.

164
00:08:21,580 --> 00:08:24,172
Just a few hundred feet
away from that switch.

165
00:08:24,172 --> 00:08:27,730
>> Yeah and
that is important especially if you're

166
00:08:27,730 --> 00:08:31,480
a business environment you want
a dedicated reliable speed.

167
00:08:31,480 --> 00:08:34,590
And so things like DSL and cable

00:17:50,420 --> 00:17:54,490

00:18:27,730 --> 00:18:33,980

00:18:33,980 --> 00:18:37,760

00:18:53,170 --> 00:18:56,110
And it will say,

00:18:56,110 --> 00:19:02,620

00:19:02,620 --> 00:19:04,881

00:19:04,881 --> 00:19:08,110

00:19:08,110 --> 00:19:11,260

00:19:11,260 --> 00:19:13,550

00:19:21,740 --> 00:19:26,040

00:19:26,040 --> 00:19:31,250

00:19:48,470 --> 00:19:49,370

With frame relay,

00:19:56,910 --> 00:20:00,670
They have circuit numbers and

00:20:00,670 --> 00:20:03,650

00:20:03,650 --> 00:20:04,280

00:20:10,440 --> 00:20:12,370

00:20:12,370 --> 00:20:14,620
